COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  L.D. 390  1

REPORT C  3 
APPROPRIATIONS AND FINANCIAL AFFAIRS  4 
Reproduced and distributed under the direction of the Clerk of the House.  5 
STATE OF MAINE  6 
HOUSE OF REPRESENTAT IVES  7 
128TH LEGISLATURE  8 
FIRST REGULAR SESSIO N 9 
COMMITTEE AM ENDMENT “C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390, Bill, “An Act Making 10 
Unified Appropriations and Allocations for the Expenditures of State Government, 11 
General Fund and Other Funds and Changing Certain Provisions of the Law Necessary to 12 
the Proper Operations of State Gov ernment for the Fiscal Years Ending June 30, 2018 13 
and June 30, 2019”  14 
Amend the bill by striking out everything after the title and inserting the following:  15 
'Emergency preamble. Whereas, acts and resolves of the Legislature do not 16 
become effective until 90 days after adjournment unless enacted as emergencies; and  17 
Whereas, the 90 -day period may not terminate until after the beginning of the next 18 
fiscal year; and  19 
Whereas, certain obligations and expenses incident to the operation of state 20 
departments and insti tutions will become due and payable immediately; and  21 
Whereas, in the judgment of the Legislature, these facts create an emergency within 22 
the meaning of the Constitution of Maine and require the following legislation as 23 
immediately necessary for the preserv ation of the public peace, health and safety; now, 24 
therefore,  25 
Be it enacted by the People of the State of Maine as follows:  26 
PART A  27 
Sec. A -1.  Appropriations and allocations.  The following appropriations and 28 
allocations are made.  29 
ADMINISTRATIVE AND FINANCI AL SERVICES, DEPARTMENT OF  30

program to the Administration - Human Resources program within the same fund.  13

Administration - Human Resources 0038  19 
Initiative: Eliminates one vacant Plumber II position and one vacant Boiler Engineer 20 
position from the Building and Grounds Operations program, General Fund. This 21 
initiative also transfe rs one vacant Space Management Specialist position and one vacant 22 
High Voltage Electrician position from the Buildings and Grounds Operations program to 23 
the Administration - Human Resources program within the same fund and reorganizes the 24 
High Voltage Elec trician position to a Public Service Manager II position and the Space 25 
Management Specialist position to a Public Service Manager III position.  26

Initiative: Transfers one Public Service Coordinator I position from the Public 33 
Improvements - Planning/Construction - Administration program to the Administration - 34 
Hum an Resources program within the same fund to realign department resources to areas 35 
of greatest need. The employee retains all rights as a classified employee, as well as all 36 GENERAL FUND  2017 -18 2018 -19

Management Specialist position to a Public Service Manager III position.  14

Initiative: Transfers one Public Service Coordinator I position from the Public 6 
Improvements - Planning/Construction - Administration program to the Administrati on - 7 
Human Resources program within the same fund to realign department resources to areas 8 
of greatest need. The employee retains all rights as a classified employee, as well as all 9 
accrued fringe benefits, including but not limited to vacation and sick le ave, health and 10 
life insurances and retirement benefits.  11

for Local Schools program to the School Finance and Operations program within the 32 
same fund and reorganizes the position from range 25 to range 28. This reorganization 33 
will be funded with a transfer from the All Other line category in the General Purpose 34 
Aid for Local Schools program, General Fund to the Personal Services line category in 35 
the School Finance and Operations program, General Fund.  36

Position details are on file in the Bureau of the Budget.  19

Initiative: Transfers one Public Service Executive II position, 3 Educatio n Specialist III 2 
positions, one Office Specialist I Manager position and 3 Office Associate II positions 3 
from the School Finance and Operations program, General Fund, one Education 4 
Specialist III position, one Public Service Manager II position and one par t-time Office 5

Education Specialist III position from the Leadership Team program, General Fund and 7 
one Education Specialist III position from the Leadership Team program, Feder al 8 
Expenditures Fund to the Higher Education and Educator Support Services program.  9

All Other and Personal Services within the Department of Education as a result of an 24 
internal review and reorganization of department structure. Establishes one Management 25 
Analyst I position and one Public Service Coordinator I position a nd eliminates one 26 
vacant Regional Education Representative position and one vacant Office Associate II 27 
position as part of the reorganization of department structure. Position details are on file 28 
in the Bureau of the Budget.  29

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  Office of Policy and Management Z135  1 
Initiative : Transfers one Public Service Executive II position and one Economist position 2 
and associated All Other from the Executive Department, Office of Policy and 3 
Management program to the Department of Administrative and Financial Services, Office 4 
of the Commis sioner - Administrative and Financial Services program within the same 5 
fund.  Employees retain all rights as classified employees, as well as all accrued fringe 6 
benefits, including, but not limited to, vacation and sick leave; health and life insurance; 7 
and retirement benefits.  8

within the same program and adjusts All Other related to STA -CAP charges.  Also 23

Expenditures Fund within the same program and adjusts All Other related to STA -CAP 26 
charges to be in line with federal match requirements. Position detail is on file in the 27 
Bureau of the Budget.  28

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  Initiative: Continues one limited -period Social Services Program Specialist I position 1 
through June 8, 2019 in the Food Supplement Administration program, Federal 2 
Expenditures Fund and provides funding in All Other to support the position. This 3 
position was originally established as a limited -period position by Financial Order 4 
000674 F2 and continued by Public Law 2013, chapter 368 and by Public Law 2015, 5 
chapter 267.  6

General Assistance - Reimbursement to Cities and Towns 0130  23 
Initiative: Reduces funding in the general assistance program for a person who has 24 
exhausted the 60 -month lifetime limit on Temporary Assistance for Needy Families 25 
program benefits and is therefore ineligible to receive municipal general assistance 26 
program benefits and for an applicant for general assistance who voluntarily abandons or 27 
refuses to use an available resource witho ut just cause and is therefore ineligible to 28 
receive general assistance to replace the abandoned resource for a period of 120 days.  29

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 389 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  Initiative: Reorganizes one vacant Behavioral  Health Program Coordinator position to a 1 
Comprehensive Health Planner II position and transfers the position from the Mental 2 
Health Services - Community program to the Office of Substance Abuse and Mental 3 
Health Services program within the same fund. Reor ganizes one vacant Social Services 4 
Program Specialist I position to a Comprehensive Health Planner II position, increases 5 
the  hours of the position from 54 hours biweekly to 80 hours biweekly and transfers the 6 
position from the Mental Health Services - Community program to the Office of 7 
Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services program within the same fund. Also, 8 
eliminates one vacant Librarian I position from the Office of Substance Abuse and 9 
Mental Health Services program.  10

§4775.  Payment; appropriations  26 
The Until the 2018 -2019 school year, the  department shall pay 50% of the in -state 27 
tuition for the first 6 credit hours taken each semester by a student at an eligible 28 
institution and up to 12 credit hours per academic year.  The eligible institution may not 29 
make any additional tuition charges for the course but may i mpose fees and charges, 30 
other than tuition, that are ordinarily imposed on students not covered by this chapter.  31 
Funds appropriated to the department to carry out the purposes of this chapter must be in 32 
addition to the customary and ongoing amounts approp riated for general purpose aid for 33 
local schools.  34 
Beginning with the 2018 -2019 school year, the department shall reimburse each 35 
eligible institution the cost of in -state tuition up to the maximum rate, calculated as 36 
follows: 50% of the average in -state tui tion rate for the highest and lowest in -state tuition 37 
rates established by the University of Maine System for eligible institutions within the 38 
system for the first 6 credit hours taken each semester by a student at an eligible 39 
institution and up to 12 cred it hours per academic year. The eligible institution may not 40 
make any additional tuition charges for the course but may impose fees and charges, 41 
other than tuition, that are ordinarily imposed on students not covered by this chapter. 42 
Funds appropriated to the department to carry out the purposes of this chapter must be in 43

Sec. C -11.  20-A MRSA §5806, sub -§2, as repealed and replaced by PL 2013, c. 3 
497, §1, is amended to read:  4 
2.  Maximum allowable tuition.   The maximum allowable tuition charged to a 5 
school administrative unit by a private school is the rate established under subsection 1 or 6 
the state average per public secondary student cost as adjusted, whi chever is lower, plus 7 
an insured value factor.  The insured value factor is computed by dividing 5% of the 8 
insured value of school buildings and equipment by the average number of pupils 9 
enrolled in the school on October 1st and April 1st of the year immed iately before the 10 
school year for which the tuition charge is computed.  From school year 2009 -2010 to 11 
school year 2013 -2014, a school administrative unit is not required to pay an insured 12 
value factor greater than 5% of the school's tuition rate or $500 p er student, whichever is 13 
less, unless the legislative body of the school administrative unit votes to authorize its 14 
school board to pay a higher insured value factor that is no greater than 10% of the 15 
school’s tuition rate per student.  For the 2014 -2015 s chool year, a school administrative 16 
unit is not required to pay an insured value factor greater than 6% of the school's tuition 17 
rate per student, unless the legislative body of the school administrative unit votes to 18 
authorize its school board to pay a hig her insured value factor that is no greater than 10% 19 
of the school's tuition rate per student.  Beginning in the 2015 -2016 school year, a school 20 
administrative unit is not required to pay an insured value factor greater than the amount 21 
of the prior school year's insured value factor adjusted by a percentage equal to the 22 
percentage change in the state share percentage of the total cost of funding public 23 
education in the prior school year as determined by section 15671, subsection 7, 24 
paragraph C D as compared  to the applicable percentage for the current school year.  In 25 
no case may the insured value factor be less than 6% or greater than 10% of the school's 26 
tuition rate per student, unless the legislative body of the school administrative unit votes 27 
to authori ze its school board to pay an insured value factor that exceeds the amount 28 
otherwise permitted by this subsection by no more than 5% of the school's tuition rate per 29 
student.  For the 2013 -2014 school year only, the maximum allowable tuition charged to 30 
a school administrative unit by a private school that participates in the Maine Public 31 
Employees Retirement System must be increased above the amount otherwise permitted 32 
under this section by an amount equal to the calculated normal cost of teacher retirement  33 
for that school divided by the number of enrolled students as of October 1, 2012.  34

Sec. C -17.  20-A MRSA §8232, sub -§2, as enacted by PL 2015, c. 363, §4, is 11 
amended to read:  12 
2.  Tuition; room an d board; funding.   Students from this State may attend the 13 
school free of tuition charges.  Additional funding for students from this State may be 14 
provided within amounts appropriated for that purpose as follows.  15 
A.  The amount must be paid in 4 equal quar terly payments during the year of 16 
attendance.  The first payment must be made by July 31st.  The amount of tuition and 17 
other costs paid for all students is limited to the amount appropriated for this purpose.  18 
State funding for the school must be provided u sing the method established for public 19 
charter schools that are authorized by the commission in accordance with the funding 20 
provisions established in section 2413 -A and section 15683 -B.  To be eligible for 21 
state funding under this paragraph, a student must  have resided in Maine with a 22 
parent, other relative or guardian for at least 6 months immediately preceding 23 
application to the school.  24 
B.  Except as otherwise provided in this paragraph, effective July 1, 2018, the student 25 
or the student's parent or guard ian shall pay to the school the cost of room and board 26 
for the school year.  In the case of financial need, the State shall pay to the school the 27 
difference between the cost of room and board and the student's or the student's 28 
family's ability to pay that cost.  The board of trustees shall establish rules governing 29 
the determination of financial need and the cost and schedule of payment of room and 30 
board under this paragraph.  The determination of financial need must be based on a 31 
nationally recognized publ ic or private school financial needs assessment system.  A 32 
student may use scholarship funds in place of payment for all or part of the cost of 33 
room and board and any other fees or expenses incurred as a result of that student's 34 
enrollment at the school.  35 
Sec. C -18.  20-A MRSA §8235 -A is enacted to read:  36 
§8235 -A.  Oversight by the commission  37 
The Maine Charter School Commission, as set out in section 2405, subsection 8, shall 38 
provide oversight of the school in accordance with the following.  39 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 630 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  1.  Data collectio n; monitoring.  The commission shall collect, analyze and report 1 
all data from state assessments in accordance with the performance framework developed 2 
under section 2409, subsection 1.  The commission shall monitor the performance and 3 
legal compliance of the school, including collecting and analyzing all data to support 4 
ongoing evaluation of the school.  In order to carry out the purposes of this subsection, 5 
the school shall provide to the commission information that the commission requests in 6 
the format, with the content and within the time schedules, established by the 7 
commission.  8 
2.  Notification of unsatisfactory performance or compliance.  If the school's 9 
performance or legal compliance appears unsatisfactory, the commission shall promptly 10 
provide writ ten notice to the school of identified problems and provide reasonable 11 
opportunity for the school to remedy those problems.  The commission shall provide the 12 
commissioner with a copy of the written notice and a report of the plan developed by the 13 
school to  remedy the identified problems.  14

Sec. C -20.  20-A MRSA §13013 -A, as amended by PL 2011, c. 702, §2, is further 17 
amended to read:  18 
§13013 -A.  Schol arship fund for national board -certified teachers  19 
1.  Department of Education salary supplement.   Notwithstanding any other 20 
provision of law, the Department of Education shall provide a public school teacher or a 21 
teacher in a publicly supported secondary s chool who has attained certification from the 22 
National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, or its successor organization, with 23 
an annual national board certification salary supplement for the life of the certificate.  The 24 
salary supplement must be a dded to the teacher's base salary and must be considered in 25 
the calculation for contributions to the Maine Public Employees Retirement System.  If a 26 
nationally certified teacher is no longer employed as a teacher, the supplement ceases.  27 
The amount of the salary supplement is:  28 
A.  For fiscal year 2012 -13, $2,500;  29 
B.  For fiscal year 2013 -14, $2,750; and  30 
C.  For fiscal year 2014 -15 and succeeding years, $3,000.  31 
1-A.  Funding revenue.   The National Board Certification Salary Supplement Fund 32 
is established as a nonlapsing dedicated fund within the Department of Education 33 
beginning in fiscal year 2012 -13. The salary supplement under subsection 1 must be 34 
funded from fees collected by the department pursuant to section 13007, subsection 1.  35 
2.  Local filing; certif ication.   On or before October 15th annually, the 36 
superintendent of schools of a school administrative unit or the chief administrative 37 
officer of a publicly supported secondary school or a career and technical education 38 
region shall file with the commissi oner a certified list of national board -certified teachers 39 
eligible to receive the salary supplement pursuant to subsection 1.  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 631 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  3.  Payment.   The department shall provide the salary supplement to school 1 
administrative units and publicly supported secondary schools for eligible teachers no 2 
later than February 15th of each year.  3 
4.  Expend funds.   A school administrative unit or a publicly supported secondary 4 
school may expend funds received through the salary supplement under subsection 1 5 
without calling for a special meeting of the local legislative body.  6 
5.  Scholarship fund.   The National Board Certification Scholarship Fund is 7 
established as a nonlapsing dedicated fund, referred to in this subsection as "the 8 
scholarship fund," within the Department of Educ ation to encourage teachers to apply to 9 
and enroll in the certification program offered by the National Board for Professional 10 
Teaching Standards or its successor organization, referred to in this subsection and 11 
subsection 6 as "the certification program."   A school administrative unit or a publicly 12 
supported secondary school may request scholarship funds on behalf of its teachers who 13 
meet the requirements set forth in subsection 6.  The department shall award funds 14 
according to this subsection.  15 
A.  In fisc al year 2012 -13, the department shall allocate $50,000 from fees collected 16 
by the department pursuant to section 13007, subsection 1 to the scholarship fund.  17 
The department shall award an amount equal to the cost of the certification program 18 
less any othe r funds received by the applicant on a first -come first -served basis for 19 
the first 20 teachers accepted into the certification program annually.  20 
B.  Beginning in fiscal year 2013 -14, the department shall allocate $75,000 from fees 21 
collected by the departme nt pursuant to section 13007, subsection 1 each fiscal year 22 
to the scholarship fund.  The department shall award an amount equal to the cost of 23 
enrollment in the certification program less any other funds received by the applicant 24 
to not more than 30 teach ers accepted into the program annually . 25 
6.  Eligibility requirements.  In order to receive scholarship funds according to 26 
subsection 5 on behalf of a teacher, the school administrative unit or a publicly supported 27 
secondary school must certify to the depar tment that the teacher:  28 
A.  Is currently employed by a school administrative unit or a publicly supported 29 
secondary school;  30 
B.  Has completed at least 3 years of teaching in the State;  31 
C.  Has agreed to mentor at least one other teacher employed in the Sta te through the 32 
national board certification process to apply to and enroll in the certification program;  33 
D.  Has provided documentation of acceptance into the certification program; and  34 
E.  Has disclosed any other funds received to cover the cost of the ce rtification 35 
program.  36 
7.  Nonlapsing funds.   Any unencumbered balance of the National Board 37 
Certification Scholarship Fund under subsection 5 remaining at the end of a fiscal year 38 
may not lapse but must be carried forward to be used for the same purpose.  39 
Sec. C-21.  20-A MRSA §15671, sub -§1-A, as amended by PL 2015, c. 389, Pt. 40 
C, §2, is further amended to read:  41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 632 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  1-A.  State funding for kindergarten to grade 12 public education.  Beginning in 1 
fiscal year 2017 -18 2018 -19 and in each fiscal year thereafter unti l the state share 2 
percentage of the total cost of funding public education from kindergarten to grade 12 3 
reaches 55% pursuant to subsection 7, paragraph B , the State shall increase the state share 4 
percentage of the funding for the cost of essential program s and services by at least one 5 
percentage point per year over the percentage of the previous year and the department, in 6 
allocating funds, shall make this increase in funding a priority.  For those fiscal years that 7 
the funding appropriated or allocated fo r the cost of essential programs and services is not 8 
sufficient to increase the state share percentage of the total cost of funding public 9 
education from kindergarten to grade 12 by at least one percentage point, no new 10 
programs or initiatives may be estab lished for kindergarten to grade 12 public education 11 
within the department that would divert funds that would otherwise be distributed as 12 
general purpose aid for local schools pursuant to subsection 5.  13 
Sec. C -22.  20-A MRSA §15671, sub -§5-A, as amended by PL 2015, c. 267, Pt. 14 
C, §5, is further amended to read:  15 
5-A.  Funds from casino slot machines or table games.  Revenues received by the 16 
department from casino slot machines or casino table games pursuant to Title 8, section 17 
1036, subsection 2 -A, paragraph A or Title 8, section 1036, subsection 2 -B, paragraph A 18 
must be distributed until the end of fiscal year 2014 -15 as general purpose aid for local 19 
schools, and each school administrative unit shall make its own determination as to how 20 
to allocate these reso urces.  Beginning in fiscal year 2017 -18, $4,000,000 in revenues 21 
must be distributed by the department to provide start -up funds for approved public 22 
preschool programs for children 4 years of age in accordance with chapter 203, 23 
subchapter 3.   Neither the G overnor nor the Legislature may divert the revenues payable 24 
to the department to any other fund or for any other use. Any proposal to enact or amend 25 
a law to allow distribution of the revenues paid to the department from casino slot 26 
machines or casino tabl e games for another purpose must be submitted to the Legislative 27 
Council and to the joint standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over 28 
education matters at least 30 days prior to any vote or public hearing on the proposal.  29

calculate the full -value education mill rate  that is required to raise the statewide total 15

year 2005 -06 to fiscal year 2008 -09 and may not exceed 9.0 mills in fiscal year 2005 - 19

15.  Special education budgetary hardship adjustment.  Beginning in fiscal year 3 
2018 -19, the following provisions apply to adjustments for special education budgetary 4 
hardships.  5 
A.  If a school administrative unit determined eligibl e pursuant to paragraph B 6 
petitions the commissioner and demonstrates that the unexpected education costs of 7 
placement of a student in a special education program will cause a budgetary 8 
hardship, the commissioner may provide to the unit an amount not to ex ceed the 9 
allowable costs of the placement less 3 times the statewide special education EPS 10 
per-pupil rate for in -district placements or less 4 times the statewide special education 11 
EPS per -pupil rate for out -of-district placements. The allowable costs are those 12 
special education costs described in section 15672, subsection 30 -A, paragraphs A 13 
and B.  14 
B.  The commissioner shall determine that a school administrative unit is eligible for 15 
an adjustment under paragraph A if:  16 
(1)  The student's placement is a resu lt of an appeal approved by the 17 
commissioner pursuant to section 5205, subsection 6 or the student became the 18 
fiscal responsibility of the school administrative unit after the passage of that 19 
unit's budget for the current fiscal year; and  20 
(2)  The school a dministrative unit's unexpected allowable costs result in a 5% or 21 
more increase in the percentage of the unit's special education budget category to 22 
the unit's total budget excluding the debt service budget category.  23 
C.  The funds for adjustments under par agraph A are limited to the amount 24 
appropriated by the Legislature for that purpose, and any unexpended balance from 25 
another program's appropriated amounts under this chapter may be applied by the 26 
commissioner toward the adjustments.  27 
D.  A school administr ative unit may expend the funds from the adjustment under 28 
paragraph A without seeking approval by the unit's legislative body.  29

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  C.  The commissioner shall pay only approved special edu cation costs and supportive 1 
services, including transportation, authorized by this subsection for state agency 2 
clients and may not allocate for those special education costs and supportive services, 3 
including transportation, incurred by the school administ rative unit for state agency 4 
clients in the base years starting July 1, 1985, and every base year thereafter.  5

department in the allocation year at 100% of actual costs.  8

under this sect ion. 11

agency clients allowable school -based costs that represent the State's portion of 13

Health a nd Human Services must be made pursuant to a schedule agreed upon by the 15

school administrative units or private schools for institutional residents within the limits 19

statewide education research institute.  23

commissioner may expend and disburse funds limited  to the amount appropriated by the 25 
Legislature to carry out the purposes of Public Law 1995, chapter 649, sections 5 and 8.  26

compilation and an alysis of education data with a statewide education research institute.  29 
7.  Disbursement limitations.   The funds disbursed in accordance with this section 30 
are limited to the amounts appropriated by the Legislature for these purposes.  31 
8.  Laptop program.   The commissioner may pay costs attributed to the contracted 32 
support services and annual payments for a program that provides laptop computers to 33

Sec. C -53.  Authorization of payments.  If the State's continued obligation for 11 
any individual component contained in those sections of this Part that set the total cost of 12 
funding public education from kindergarten to grade 12 and the local and state 13 
contributions for that purpose exceeds the l evel of funding provided for that component, 14 
any unexpended balances occurring in other programs may be applied to avoid proration 15 
of payments for any individual component. Any unexpended balances from this Part may 16 
not lapse but must be carried forward fo r the same purpose.  17 
Sec. C -54.  Limit of State's obligation.  Those sections of this Part that set the 18 
total cost of funding public education from kindergarten to grade 12 and the local and 19 
state contributions for that purpose may not be construed to requi re the State to provide 20 
payments that exceed the appropriation of funds for general purpose aid for local schools 21 
for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2017 and ending June 30, 2018.  22 
Sec. C -55.  Development of funding plan.  The commissioner shall develop a 23 
plan for the funding of public education from kindergarten to grade 12 by using the local 24 
and state contributions. The plan for a new school funding formula must be based on 25 
providing direct instruction and support for student learning and include a stat ewide 26 
teacher contract and the implementation of a system to measure and ensure that school 27 
administrative units are held accountable for the intended use of the state funds. The new 28 
school funding formula must ensure that direct instructional programs and  services are 29 
available to all students and be available in all schools on an equitable basis. The new 30 
school funding formula must be presented to the Legislature for consideration no later 31 
than the 2019 -2020 school year.  32 
Sec. C -56.  Effective dates.  The following sections of this Part have the following 33 
effective dates.  34 
1.  Those sections of this Part that amend the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 20 -A, 35 
section 13013 -A and section 15683 -B, subsection 3 take effect July 1, 2017.  36 
2.  Those sections of this Pa rt that repeal Title 20 -A, section 4722 -A, subsection 4; 37 
section 15680, subsection 1, paragraph A; section 15681, subsection 6; section 15688 -A, 38 
subsection 3; and section 15688 -A, subsections 5 and 7 take effect July 1, 2017.  39 
3.  That section of this Part that enacts Title 20 -A, section 8235 -A takes effect July 1, 40 
2017.  41  State contribution to the total cost of 
courses for credit at postsecondary 
institutions for fiscal year 2017 -18

Sec. I -1.  36 MRSA §691, sub -§1, ¶A, as amended by PL 20 09, c. 571, Pt. II, §1 19 
and affected by §5, is further amended to read:  20 
A.  "Eligible business equipment" means qualified property that, in the absence of 21 
this subchapter, would first be subject to assessment under this Part on or after April 22 
1, 2008.  "Eli gible business equipment" includes, without limitation, repair parts, 23 
replacement parts, replacement equipment, additions, accessions and accessories to 24 
other qualified business property that first became subject to assessment under this 25 
Part before April 1, 2008 if the part, addition, equipment, accession or accessory 26 
would, in the absence of this subchapter, first be subject to assessment under this Part 27 
on or after April 1, 2008.  "Eligible business equipment" also includes inventory 28 
parts.  29 
"Eligible bus iness equipment" does not include:  30 
(1) Office furniture, including, without limitation, tables, chairs, desks, 31 
bookcases, filing cabinets and modular office partitions;  32 
(2) Lamps and lighting fixtures used primarily for the purpose of providing 33 
general pur pose office or worker lighting;  34 
(3) Property owned or used by an excluded person;  35 
(4) Telecommunications personal property subject to the tax imposed by section 36 
457; 37 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 652 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (5)  Gambling machines or devices, including any device, machine, paraphernalia 1 
or equipme nt that is used or usable in the playing phases of any gambling activity 2 
as that term is defined in Title 8, section 1001, subsection 15, whether that 3 
activity consists of gambling between persons or gambling by a person involving 4 
the playing of a machine.  "Gambling machines or devices" includes, without 5 
limitation:  6 
(a)  Associated equipment as defined in Title 8, section 1001, subsection 2;  7 
(b)  Computer equipment used directly and primarily in the operation of a 8 
slot machine as defined in Title 8, section  1001, subsection 39;  9 
(c)  An electronic video machine as defined in Title 17, section 1831, 10 
subsection 4;  11 
(d)  Equipment used in the playing phases of lottery schemes; and  12 
(e)  Repair and replacement parts of a gambling machine or device;  13 
(6)  Property l ocated at a retail sales facility and used primarily in a retail sales 14 
activity unless the property is owned by a business that operates a retail sales 15 
facility in the State exceeding 100,000 square feet of interior customer selling 16 
space that is used prim arily for retail sales and whose Maine -based operations 17 
derive less than 30% of their total annual revenue on a calendar year basis from 18 
sales that are made at a retail sales facility located in the State.  For purposes of 19 
this subparagraph, the following terms have the following meanings:  20 
(a)  "Primarily" means more than 50% of the time;  21 
(b)  "Retail sales activity" means an activity associated with the selection and 22 
purchase of goods or services or the rental of tangible personal property.  23 
"Retail sales activity" does not include production as defined in section 1752, 24 
subsection 9 -B; and  25 
(c)  "Retail sales facility" means a structure used to serve customers who are 26 
physically present at the facility for the purpose of selecting and purchasing 27 
goods or ser vices at retail or for renting tangible personal property.  "Retail 28 
sales facility" does not include a separate structure that is used as a 29 
warehouse or call center facility;  30 
(7)  Property that is not entitled to an exemption by reason of the additional 31 
limitations imposed by subsection 2; or 32 
(8)  Personal property that would otherwise be entitled to exemption under this 33 
subchapter used primarily to support a telecommunications antenna used by a 34 
telecommunications business subject to the tax imposed by sec tion 457 .; or 35 
(9)  Photocopiers and mail postage machines.  36 
Notwithstanding section 6651, subsection 1, beginning April 1, 2018, "eligible 37 
business equipment" also means all eligible property under chapter 915 that was 38 
placed in service after April 1, 1995 and on or before April 1, 2017.  39

1.  Eligible property.  "Eligible property" means qualified business property first 13

the S tate, after April 1, 1995 but does not include property that is eligible business 24

Sec. I -4.  36 MRSA §6652, sub -§4, as amended by PL 2013, c. 368, Pt. K, §1, is 27 
further amended to read:  28 
4.  Reimbursement percentage.   The reimbursement under this chapter is an amount 29 
equal to the percentage specified in paragraphs A and B of taxes assessed and paid with 30 
respect to each item of eligible property, except that for claims filed for application 31 
periods that begin on August 1, 2006, August 1, 2009, August 1, 2010 or August 1, 2013 , 32 
the reimbursement is 90% of that amount and, for claims filed for the application period 33 
that begins on August 1, 2014, the reimburseme nt is 80% of that amount and for claims 34 
filed for the application period that begins on August 1, 2017 and for subsequent years, 35 
the reimbursement is 90% of that amount . 36 
A.  For each of the first to 12th years for which reimbursement is made, the 37 
percentag e is 100%.  38 
B.  Pursuant to section 699, subsection 2, reimbursement under this chapter after the 39 
12th year for which reimbursement is made is according to the following percentages 40 
of taxes assessed and paid with respect to each item of eligible property.  41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 654 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (1)  For the 13th year for which reimbursement is made, the percentage is 75%.  1 
(2)  For the 14th year for which reimbursement is made, the percentage is 70%.  2 
(3)  For the 15th year for which reimbursement is made, the percentage is 65%.  3 
(4)  For the 16th y ear for which reimbursement is made, the percentage is 60%.  4 
(5)  For the 17th year for which reimbursement is made, the percentage is 55%.  5 
(6)  For the 18th year for which reimbursement is made and for subsequent years, 6 
the percentage is 50%.  7

the "commission," consists of 5 members appointed as follows:  two members appointed 2 
by the Governor; one member recommended for appointment to the Governor by the 3 
President of the Senate; one member recommended for appointment to the Governor by 4 
the Speaker of the House of Representativ es; and one member appointed by the other 5

members must be appointed within 15 days of the effe ctive date of this section and serve 8 
until January 1997.   The commission members recommended for appointment to the 9

members appointed by the Governor must be appointed in J anuary 2019 and serve a 11

one-year term.   Thereafter, the all commission members are appointe d in January of 14

of the Executive Department, the Legislature or the Judicial Department.  Each 16

economic forecasting.  18

of the unexpired term, except as otherwise provided in thi s section.  21 
If one or more positions on the commission remains unfilled on the 16th day after the 22 
effective date of this section or  the expeditious filling of a vacancy is required to enable 23 
the commission to perform its duties in an efficient and timely ma nner, the Governor 24 
shall make those appointments at such times and in such a manner as the Governor 25 
determines necessary.  26 
Sec. N -2.  5 MRSA §1710 -A, as amended by PL 2007, c. 539, Pt. Q, §1, is further 27 
amended to read:  28 
§1710 -A.  Duties of commission  29 
1.  Duties.  The Consensus Economic Forecasting Commission shall develop 5-year 30 
and 10 -year macroeconomic secular trend forecasts and one -year, 2 -year and 4 -year 31 
economic forecasts  for the current fiscal biennium and the next 2 fiscal biennia . 32 
2.  Economic assum ptions.  The commission shall submit recommendations for state 33 
economic assumptions for the next fiscal biennium and analyze economic assumptions 34 
for the current fiscal biennium, which must be approved by a majority of the commission 35 
members.   No later tha n November 1st of each even -numbered year and April 1st of each 36 
odd-numbered year , the commission shall submit to the Governor, the Legislative 37 
Council, the Revenue Forecasting Committee and the joint standing committee of the 38 
Legislature having jurisdicti on over appropriations and financial affairs a report that 39 
presents the analyses, findings and recommendations for state economic assumptions  for 40 
the next 2 fiscal biennia and analyze  economic assumptions related to revenue forecasting 41 
for the next  for the  current  fiscal biennium , which must be approved by a majority of the 42 
commission members .  In its report, the commission shall fully describe the methodology 43 
employed in reaching its recommendations.  44 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 657 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  3.  Current biennium adjustments.  No later than April 1 st and  November 1st of 1 
each odd -numbered year and no later than February 1st and November 1st  of each 2 
even -numbered year the commission shall submit to the Governor, the Legislative 3 
Council, the Revenue Forecasting Committee and the joint standing committe e of the 4 
Legislature having jurisdiction over appropriations and financial affairs a report that 5 
presents the commission's findings and recommendations for adjustments to the 6 
economic assumptions for the current fiscal biennium  all forecast years .  In each  report 7 
the commission shall fully describe the methodology employed in reaching its 8 
recommendations.  9 
4.  Alternative economic scenarios.  No later than February 1st of each 10 
even -numbered year the commission shall provide to the State Budget Officer, the S tate 11 
Economist and the Associate Commissioner for Tax Policy at least 2 additional economic 12 
forecasts that assume potential economic recession scenarios of varying levels of severity.  13 
These additional forecasts must include economic assumptions for the cu rrent fiscal 14 
biennium and the next 2 fiscal biennia.  In each report the commission shall fully describe 15 
the methodology employed in reaching its recommendations.  16

further amended to read:  3 
§1725 -A.  Risk management  4 
1.  Creation and authority.   The Department of Administrative and Financial 5 
Services is designated as the agency through which this chapter is admini stered.  The 6 
Director of the Bureau of General Services, in this chapter called the "director,"  State 7 
Controller  is empowered with such authority as necessary to carry out the purposes of this 8 
chapter.  9 
Risk management responsibilities are under the supervi sion and administrative control of 10 
the Director of the Bureau of General Services  State Controller . 11 
2.  State Controller.   The commissioner shall appoint  direct  the Director of the 12 
Bureau of General Services, in this chapter called the "director,"  State Co ntroller  to 13 
administer the State's policy on insurance management, as developed through the 14 
authority of this chapter.  The director  State Controller  or the director's  State Controller's  15 
designee must be knowledgeable of insurance practices and principles and must be 16 
qualified by actual experience in the field of risk management to carry out the purposes of 17 
this chapter.  18 
3.  Personnel.   The director  State Controller  may employ such assistants and 19 
employees as are necessary, and distribute the risk managemen t duties among such 20 
persons as the director  State Controller  considers necessary for economy and efficiency 21 
of administration. Employees are subject to the Civil Service Law.  22

director  State Controller  or any other  employee be licensed under Title 24 -A, as an agent, 29

Sec. O -3.  5 MRSA §1728 -A, as amended by PL 1993, c. 470, §1, is further 31 
amended to read:  32 
§1728-A.  Powers and duties of the State Controller  33 
1.  Duties.   The director  State Controller  shall provide insurance advice and services 34 
for all forms of insurance for State Government and any department or agency of State 35 
Government except for those depart ments or agencies and those types of insurance 36 
otherwise provided for by law through the self -insurance fund and to other entities 37 
designated as entitled to advice and services through the state -administered fund pursuant 38 
to section 1737.  The director  State Controller  is responsible for the acquisition and 39 
administration of all insurance purchased by the State, including the authority to purchase 40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 659 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  insurance for the State for automobile, fire, liability and any other type of coverage 1 
necessary to protect the  State from financial loss. The director  State Controller  may enter 2 
into contracts for various types of claims management services in order to ensure the 3 
most economically advantageous insurance protection in the operation of the State's 4 
insurance coverage  program.  In these regards, the director  State Controller  has the 5 
following duties:  6 
A.  To review annually the entire subject of insurance as it applies to all state 7 
property and activities and other persons pursuant to this section, and to provide to 8 
the Commissioner of Administrative and Financial Services a statement of its 9 
activities during the year ending the preceding June 30th. This report must include:  10 
(1)  An evaluation of the state insurance program;  11 
(2)  A complete statement of all types and c osts of insurance in effect;  12 
(3)  Names of agents and companies of record; and  13 
(4)  Such other matters as the director  State Controller  determines appropriate 14 
and necessary or as the commissioner may request;  15 
B.  To recommend to the Commissioner of Admin istrative and Financial Services 16 
such insurance protection as the director  State Controller  considers necessary or 17 
desirable for the protection of all state property or activities or other insureds under 18 
this section;  19 
C.  Pursuant to programs approved by t he Commissioner of Administrative and 20 
Financial Services, to provide insurance protection for property and liability in 21 
accordance with the Maine Tort Claims Act, Title 14, section 8116, and premises 22 
liability, when required by a state lease or private pro perty approved by the Attorney 23 
General, by self -insured retention or purchase of insurance from companies or agents 24 
licensed to do business in this State, or by both, to effect the best possible contracts as 25 
to services, coverages and costs. The purchase o f insurance under this section 26 
normally must be made upon competitive bidding, except that the director  State 27 
Controller  may, in appropriate circumstances, purchase insurance by negotiation;  28 
D.  To determine and review the values of property in which the S tate has an 29 
insurable or legal interest and recommend limits and types of insurance protection for 30 
that property;  31 
E.  To establish and promote safety and other loss prevention programs;  32 
F.  To receive and, with the assistance of the Attorney General, admin ister all claims 33 
for personal injury and property damage against the State;  34 
G.  With the assistance of the Attorney General, to pursue all claims against 3rd 35 
parties in all cases in which the State may be subrogated to the rights of injured 36 
employees or wh ere damage to state property may have resulted from the negligence 37 
of a 3rd party;  38 
H.  To administer the funds established by sections 1731 and 1737.  In performing the 39 
functions authorized by this chapter, the funds, the Commissioner of Administrative 40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 660 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  and Financial Services and the director  State Controller  are not subject to the 1 
provisions of Title 24 -A; and  2 
I.  On or before December 31, 1996 and every 3 years thereafter, to submit to the 3 
Commissioner of Administrative and Financial Services a report on t he availability 4 
and affordability of insurance advice and services to those entities participating in the 5 
state-administered fund pursuant to section 1737 and to make specific 6 
recommendations for the removal from the state -administered fund of those entiti es 7 
that do not qualify.  8 
2.  Appraisal.   In case an agreement as to the amount of loss sustained to any 9 
building or property insured under this chapter can not be arrived at between the insured 10 
entity and the director  State Controller , the loss must be refe rred to appraisal as provided 11 
by Title 24 -A, section 3002.  12 
3.  Rejection of risk.   In the event that the director  State Controller  determines that a 13 
risk may be prejudicial to the State's insurance program or to the state -administered fund 14 
established by section 1737 because of an actual or expected adverse loss ratio, the 15 
director  State Controller  may refuse to include that risk in the program until the time that 16 
the hazards of the risk have been removed or ameliorated to a satisfactory degree.  17 
When cover age is declined by the director  State Controller , the department, agency or 18 
entity in charge of the risk may request that the director  State Controller  procure separate 19 
insurance from any authorized insurance company, and the premium for that separate 20 
insurance is a proper charge against the department, agency or entity responsible for the 21 
property.  22 
4.  Forms and rules.   The director  State Controller  may prescribe forms of policies, 23 
proofs of loss and other forms and may adopt rules as are necessary or expe dient for the 24 
proper administration of this chapter.  25 
5.  Actuarial review.   Once every 3 years, and more frequently if determined prudent 26 
by the Commissioner of Administrative and Financial Services, the director  State 27 
Controller  shall arrange for a review  of the reserves of the state -administered fund by a 28 
qualified actuary who is a member in good standing of the Casualty Actuarial Society.  29 
The actuary shall issue an opinion on the adequacy of reserves of the state -administered 30 
fund to cover the estimated  ultimate liability of the state -administered fund.  Costs for 31 
this service must be paid from the Risk Management Fund.  32

given year may not exceed 5% of the  self-insurance fund as of July 1st of that fiscal year.  44
