Sec. FFFF -5.  22 MRSA §3762, sub -§§21 and 22 are enacted to read:  10 
21.  Job readiness requirement.  Before TANF assistance may be granted to an 11 
applicant by the department, the applicant must attend a jo b readiness and vocational 12 
evaluation and training program administered by the department or its designee.  13 
22.  Denial of assistance based on quitting or losing a job without good cause.  14 
An applicant or recipient of TANF assistance must be denied TANF ass istance as 15 
described in this subsection.  16 
A.  If an applicant or recipient of TANF has quit or has lost a job without good cause 17 
in the 30 days prior to application, during the application -processing period or after 18 
application approval, the family will be ineligible for TANF for a period of 3 months. 19 
The ineligibility period includes the month employment ended and the next 2 months.  20 
B.  A penalty for quitting a job or losing a job is applied when an individual:  21 
(1)  Voluntarily quits a job without good caus e as defined by rule of the 22 
department;  23 
(2)  Leaves a job unannounced or does not return to work without good cause as 24 
defined by rule of the department; or  25 
(3)  Has been warned about performance or behavior by the employer, continues 26 
the objectionable con duct after the warning and is subsequently terminated.  27 
C.  The penalty under paragraph A is not applied when:  28 
(1)  An individual has terminated a self -employment enterprise; or  29 
(2)  There is good cause as defined by rule of the department.  30 
D.  There is no cure for the penalty for quitting or losing a job.  Once the penalty 31 
period begins, it continues for the full 3 months, even if the individual obtains 32 
employment.  33 
The department shall adopt routine technical rules, as defined in Title 5, chapter 375, 34 
subch apter 2 -A, to implement the provisions of this subsection, including determining 35 
what constitutes "good cause."  36

Sec. FFFF -12.  22 MRSA §3785 -B is enacted to read:  12 
§3785 -B.  Domestic violence exception from sanctions for failure to participate  13 
An individual may not be sanctioned under ASPIRE -TANF or Temporary Assistance 14 
for Needy Families for failure to participate in the ASPIRE -TANF program if that 15 
individual is unable to  participate because of physical injuries or the psychological effects 16 
of abuse; because of legal proceedings, counseling or other activities related to abuse; 17 
because the abuser actively interferes with the individual's participation; because the 18 
location  puts the individual at risk; or for other good cause related to domestic violence.  19 
Good cause for failure to participate in ASPIRE -TANF must be found when there is 20 
reasonable and verifiable evidence of domestic violence.  For the purposes of this section , 21 
reasonable and verifiable evidence may include but is not limited to the following:  22 
1.  Records.  Court, medical, law enforcement, child protective, social services, 23 
psychological or other records that establish that the individual has been a victim of 24 
domestic violence; or  25 
2.  Sworn statements.  Sworn statements from persons other than the individual with 26 
knowledge of the circumstances affecting the individual.  27 
Each individual participating in an ASPIRE -TANF orientation must receive written 28 
and oral noti ce of what constitutes good cause for nonparticipation in ASPIRE -TANF.  29

Sec. UUUU -14.  4 MRSA §1805 -A is enacted to read:  4 
§1805 -A.  Indigency determinations; redeterminations; verifications; collections  5 
1.  Duties.  The executive director shall administer and improve reimbursement of 6 
expenses incurred by assigned counsel and contract counsel by:  7 
A.  Establishing procedures to ensure that the eligibility of defendants and civil 8 
parties is verified and revi ewed randomly and when circumstances have changed, 9 
information has changed, additional information is provided or as otherwise needed;  10 
B.  Petitioning the court to reassess the indigency of a defendant or civil party if the 11 
executive director determines th at indigency should be reassessed;  12 
C.  Providing to the commission recommendations to improve reimbursement of 13 
expenses;  14 
D.  Requiring that the amount of time spent on each case by assigned counsel or 15 
contract counsel is recorded separately for each case; and 16 
E.  Receiving from the courts collections for the costs of representation from 17 
defendants or civil parties who are found to be partially indigent or who have 18 
otherwise been determined to be able to reimburse the commission for expenses 19 
incurred by assi gned counsel or contract counsel.  20 
2.  Determination of defendant’s or civil party’s eligibility.  The executive director 21 
shall provide the court having jurisdiction over a proceeding information used to 22 
determine indigency for guidance to the court in dete rmining a defendant’s or civil 23 
party’s financial ability to obtain private counsel.  24 
3.  Partial indigency and reimbursement.  This subsection applies to partial 25 
indigency and reimbursement of expenses incurred by assigned counsel or contract 26 
counsel.  27 
A.  If the court determines that a defendant or civil party is unable to pay to obtain 28 
private counsel but is able to contribute to payment of assigned counsel or contract 29 
counsel, the court shall order the defendant or civil party to make installment 30 
payments up to the full cost of representation or to pay a fixed contribution.  The 31 
court shall remit payments received to the commission.  32 
B.  A defendant or civil party may not be required to pay for legal services in an 33 
amount greater than the expenses actually i ncurred.  34 
C.  Upon petition of a defendant or civil party who is incarcerated, the court may 35 
suspend an order for reimbursement issued pursuant to this subsection until the time 36 
of the defendant’s or civil party’s release.  37 
D.  The executive director may ent er into contracts to secure the reimbursement of 38 
fees and expenses paid by the commission as provided for in this section.  39

3.  Setoff of defendant's propert y.  When a defendant has deposited cash or other 3 
property owned by the defendant as bail or has offered real estate owned by the defendant 4

forfeited, the court, bef ore ordering the cash or other property returned to the defendant or 6

real estate or any portion of the cash, other property or real estate is subject to setoff as 8 
authorized by this section.  The court may order all or a portion of the bail owned by a 9

following:  11

Sec. UUUU -17.  Working group established.  Notwithstanding Joint Rule 353, 31 
the Working Group to Improve the Provision of Indigent Legal Services, referred to in 32 
this section as "the working group," is established.  33 
1.  Membership.   The working  group consists of 11 members appointed as follows:  34 
A.  Two members of the Senate appointed by the President of the Senate, including 35 
members from each of the 2 parties holding the largest number of seats in the 36 
Legislature;  37 
B.  Two members of the House of  Representatives appointed by the Speaker of the 38 
House, including members from each of the 2 parties holding the largest number of 39 
seats in the Legislature;  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 732 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  C.  Two members appointed by Chief Justice of the Supreme Judicial Court, at least 1 
one of whom is on a court -appointed attorney roster administered by the Maine 2 
Commission on Indigent Legal Services;  3 
D.  The Attorney General or the Attorney General's designee;  4 
E.  The Commissioner of Administrative and Financial Services or the 5 
commissioner's designee;  6 
F.  The Director of the Governor's Office of Policy and Management or the director's 7 
designee;  8 
G.  The President of the Maine Prosecutors Association or the president's designee; 9 
and 10 
H.  The Chair of the Maine Commission on Indigent Legal Services or the chair's 11 
designee.  12 
2.  Chairs.   The first -named Senate member is the Senate chair and the first -named 13 
House of Representatives member is the House chair of the working group.  14 
3.  Appointments; convening.   All appointments must be made no later than 30 days 15 
following the effective date of this section.  The appointing authorities shall notify the 16 
Executive Director of the Legislative Council once all appointments have been 17 
completed. When the appointment of all members has been completed, the chairs shall 18 
call and convene the first meeting of the working group.  If 30 days or more after the 19 
effective date of this section a majority of but not all appointments have been made, the 20 
chairs may request authority and the Legislative Council may grant authority for t he 21 
working group to meet and conduct its business.  22 
4.  Duties.   The working group shall develop recommendations to improve the 23 
delivery of indigent legal services to those eligible to receive such services in the State.  24 
The recommendations must focus on e nsuring adequate representation, increasing the 25 
efficiency in delivering legal services, verifying eligibility throughout representation and 26 
reducing costs while still fully honoring the constitutional and statutory obligations to 27 
provide  representation.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the working group 28 
may access data maintained by the Maine Commission on Indigent Legal Services and 29 
shall maintain the confidentiality of any confidential information provided to the working 30 
group.  The working group may invite the participation and input of additional interested 31 
parties and request information as necessary to carry out its duties.  32 
5.  Staff assistance.  The Legislative Council shall provide necessary staffing services 33 
to the working group.  34 
6.  Re port.   No later than December 6, 2017, the working group shall submit a report 35 
that includes its findings and recommendations, including suggested legislation, for 36 
presentation to the 2nd Regular Session of the 128th Legislature.  The Joint Standing 37 
Commit tee on Judiciary may report out to the Second Regular Session of the 128th 38 
Legislature legislation to implement recommendations on matters related to the report.  39 
Sec. UUUU -18.  Transfer from General Fund; indigent legal services.  On 40 
or immediately after J uly 1, 2018, the State Controller shall transfer $16,400,290 from the 41 
unappropriated surplus of the General Fund to the Maine Commission on Indigent Legal 42 
Services, Reserve for Indigent Legal Services program, Other Special Revenue Funds.  43

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §17-A.  Publications and technology  1 
1.  Informational publications and record searches.   The State Court 2 
Administrator may establish a fee schedule to cover the cost of printing and distribution 3 
of publications and forms, the procedures for the sale of these publications and forms and 4 
record searches performed by Judicial Department employees . 5 
2.  Fund; fees deposited.   All fees collected under this section from the sale of 6 
publications or forms must be deposited in a fund for use by the State Court 7 
Administrator to fund publications, forms and information technology.  Twenty percent 8 
of fees collected for record searches under subsection 1  must be deposited in the fund, 9 
and 80% of fees collected for such record searches must be deposited in the General 10 
Fund.  11 
3.  Fees and surcharges for electronic filing.   The Supreme Judicial Court may by 12 
court rules or administrative orders raise or establish fees for online case searches 13 
performed by Judicial Department employees and electronic document delivery and case 14 
filings and surcharges on fines to support the operating costs of maintaining an electronic 15 
filing and court information management system.  All revenues collected under t his 16 
subsection must be deposited in a fund to be used for those operating costs, including, but 17 
not limited to, costs of electronic filing, imaging and hardware, software maintenance 18 
fees and hardware maintenance fees and personnel costs.  19

3.  Weekly benefit for partial unemployment.   Each eligible individual who is 26 
partially unemployed in any week must be paid a partial benefit for that week.  The 27 
partial benefit is equal to the weekly benefit amount less the individual's weekly earnings 28 
in excess of $25 , except that, beginning the first full benefit week beginning on or after 29 
January 1, 2018, the partial benefit is equal to the weekly benefit amount less the 30 
individual's weekly earnings in excess of $100 .  The following amounts are not 31 
considered wages for purposes of this subsection:  32

Guard and organized  reserve, including base pay and allowances;  34

services person;  36

A.  At the time the status of an employing unit is ascertained to be that of an 5 
employer, the commissioner shall establish and maintain, until the employer status is 6 
terminated, for the employer an experience rating record, to which are credited all the 7

otherwise chargeable experience rating record is that of an employer whose status as 17

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  contributions, credited from the time the emp loyer first or most recently became an 1 
employer, whichever date is later, up to and including June 30th of the preceding 2 
year, including any part of the employer's contributions due for that year paid on or 3 
before July 31st of that year, exceed the employe r's benefits charged during the same 4 
period, by the employer's average annual payroll for the period of 36 consecutive 5 
months ending June 30th of the preceding year.  The employer's contribution rate is 6 
determined under subparagraphs (1) to (8).  7 
 (1)  The commissioner shall prepare a schedule listing all employers for whom a 8 
reserve ratio has been computed pursuant to this paragraph, in the order of their 9 
reserve ratios, beginning with the highest ratio.  For each employer, the schedule 10 
must show:  11 
(a)  The amount of the employer's reserve ratio;  12 
(b)  The amount of the employer's annual taxable payroll; and  13 
(c)  A cumulative total consisting of the amount of the employer's annual 14 
taxable payroll plus the amount of the annual taxable payrolls of all other 15 
empl oyers preceding the employer on the list.  16 
(2)  The commissioner shall segregate employers into contribution categories in 17 
accordance with the cumulative totals under subparagraph (1), division (c).  The 18 
contribution category is determined by the cumulative  payroll percentage limits 19 
in column B.  Each contribution category is identified by the contribution 20 
category number in column A that is opposite the figures in column B, which 21 
represent the percentage limits of each contribution category.  If an employer 's 22 
taxable payroll falls in more than one contribution category, the employer must 23 
be assigned to the lower -numbered contribution category, except that an 24 
employer may not be assigned to a higher contribution category than is assigned 25 
any other employer wi th the same reserve ratio.  26

(4)  The commissioner shall compute the predetermined yield by multiplying the 30 
ratio of  total wages to taxable wages for the preceding calendar year by the 31 
planned yield.  32

year by multiplying the predetermined yield by the experience factors for each 34 
contributio n category.  Contribution category 20 in the table in subparagraph (2) 35 
must be assigned a contribution rate of at least 5.4%.  The employer's experience 36 
factor is the percentage shown in column C in the table in subparagraph (2) that 37 
corresponds with the e mployer's contribution category in column A, except that 38 
the experience factors in column E must be used to determine the contribution 39

(6)  If, subsequent to the assignment of con tribution rates for a rate year, the 3 
reserve ratio of an employer is recomputed and changed, the employer must be 4 
placed in the position on the schedule prepared pursuant to subparagraph (1) that 5 
the employer would have occupied had the corrected reserve r atio been shown on 6 
the schedule.  The altered position on the schedule does not affect the position of 7 
any other employer.  8 
(7)  In computing the contribution rates, only the wages reported by employers 9 
liable for payment of contributions into the fund and net benefits paid that are 10 
charged to an employer's experience rating record or to the fund are considered in 11 
the computation of the average benefit cost rate and the ratio of total wages to 12 
taxable wages.  13 
(8)  Beginning January 1, 2008, all contribution r ates must be reduced by the 14 
Competitive Skills Scholarship Fund predetermined yield as defined in section 15 
1166, subsection 1, paragraph C, except that contribution category 20 under this 16 
paragraph may not be reduced below 5.4%.  17 
PART DDDDD  18 
Sec. DDDDD -1.  De partment of Labor; position review after 19 
reorganization.  The Commissioner of Labor is authorized to identify positions to be 20 
eliminated on or before June 30, 2019 pursuant to reorganizations within the Employment 21 
Security Services program and the Employmen t Services Activity program and shall 22 
submit a report regarding any positions eliminated to the joint standing committee of the 23 
Legislature having jurisdiction over appropriations and financial affairs by January 6, 24 
2020.  25 
Sec. DDDDD -2.  Calculation.  Notwit hstanding any other provision of law, the 26 
State Budget Officer shall calculate the amount of savings from the position eliminations 27 
under this Part and shall make adjustments by financial order upon approval of the 28 
Governor no later than June 30, 2019. The se eliminations are considered adjustments to 29 
authorized position count, appropriations and allocations.  30

8.  Coastal Fisheries Research, Management and Enforcement Fund.  The 24 
Coastal Fisheries Research, Management and Enforcement Fund, referred to in this 25 
subsection as "the fund," is established within the department. The fund receives all funds 26 
deposited by the commissioner pursuant to this section. All money received by the fund 27 
must be used to fund scientific research, management or enforcement activities related to 28 
marine resources.  Unexpended balances in the fund at the end of a fiscal year do not 29 
lapse but must be carried forward to the next fiscal year to be used for the purposes of the 30 
fund. Any interest earned on the money in the fund must be credited to the fund.  31

Sec. IIIII -1.  8 MRSA §1003, sub -§5 is enacted to read:  6 
5.  Additional duties of the director.  The director also serves as the director of the 7 
Gambling Contro l Unit, established as a bureau within the Department of Public Safety 8 
under Title 25, section 2902, subsection 12.  As director of the unit, the director shall 9 
administer and enforce the laws governing beano and games of chance under Title 17, 10 
chapters 13 -A and 62, respectively.  11 
PART JJJJJ  12 
Sec. JJJJJ -1.  17 MRSA §311, as amended by PL 2001, c. 342, §1, is further 13 
amended to read:  14 
§311.  Definitions  15 
As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following words 16 
shall  have the following  meanings.  17 
1.  Beano.   "Beano" means a specific kind of group game of chance, regardless of 18 
whether such a game is characterized by another name. Wherever the term "beano" is 19 
used, the word "bingo" or any other word used to characterize such a game may be 20 
interchanged. In "beano," each participant is given or sold one or more tally cards, so - 21 
called, each of which contains preprinted numbers or letters and may or may not be 22 
arranged in vertical or horizontal rows. The participant covers or marks the numbers or 23 
letters as objects similarly numbered or lettered are drawn from a receptacle and the 24 
winner or winners are determined by the sequence in which those objects are drawn.  The 25 
manner in which the winner is determined must be clearly announced or displayed  before 26 
any game is begun.  Until July 1, 1994, a game described in this subsection is "beano" 27 
and a licensee may conduct such a game regardless of whether the manner of determining 28 
the winner is specifically described as a permissible manner of determinin g the winner in 29 
rules adopted by the Chief of State Police.   For the purposes of this chapter, to hold, 30 
conduct or operate beano includes charging a fee or offering something of value to play 31 
in exchange for the opportunity to receive something of value fo r winning a game.  32 
1-A.  Commercial beano hall permit.   "Commercial beano hall permit" means 33 
written authority from the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  issued to a 34 
permittee who rents or leases premises for profit to a licensee to hold, cond uct or operate 35 
"beano."  36 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 750 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  1-B.  Chief of State Police.   "Chief of the State Police" or "chief" means the Chief of 1 
the State Police or the chief's designee.  2 
2.  Equipment.  "Equipment" shall mean  means  the receptacle and numbered objects 3 
to be drawn from it; t he master board upon which such objects are placed as drawn; the 4 
tally cards or sheets bearing such numbers to be covered and the objects used to cover 5 
them; the boards or signs, however operated, used to display the numbers as they are 6 
drawn; public addre ss systems; and any other articles essential to the operation, conduct 7 
and playing of "Beano."  8 
2-A.  Director.  "Director" means the Executive Director of the Gambling Control 9 
Board and the Gambling Control Unit.  10 
2-B.  Gambling Control Unit.  "Gambling Con trol Unit" or "unit" means the bureau 11 
within the Department of Public Safety under Title 25, section 2902, subsection 12 or an 12 
authorized representative of the Gambling Control Unit.  13 
3.  License.  "License" shall mean that  means  written authority from the Chief of the 14 
State Police  Gambling Control Unit  to hold, conduct or operate the amusement 15 
commonly known as  "Beano" for the entertainment of the public within the State of 16 
Maine. A location permit must accompany the license to be valid . 17 
4.  Licensee.  "Licen see" shall mean  means  any organization which , including a 18 
federally recognized Indian tribe in the State, that  has been granted a license by the Chief 19 
of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  to hold, conduct or operate "Beano" or 20 
"Bingo."  21 
5.  Location pe rmit.  "Location permit" shall mean  means  that card issued by the 22 
Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit , describing the premises or area in which 23 
"Beano" may be conducted. Such location permit must be accompanied by a license. 24 
Only such locations expressly described in the location permit shall be  are used for the 25 
conduct of any game.  26 
6.  Organization.  "Organization" shall mean  means  any firm, association or 27 
corporation authorized to conduct "Beano" in accordance with this chapter.  28 
7.  Period.  "Period" shall mean  means  the number of calendar weeks authorized by a 29 
single license for the operation of "Beano" or "Bingo."  30 
7-A.  Permittee.   "Permittee" means an individual, corporation, partnership or 31 
unincorporated association that rents or leases a buil ding or facilities for profit to a 32 
licensee to hold, conduct or operate "beano."  33 
7-B.  Wild number beano.   "Wild number beano" means a beano occasion, game or 34 
series of beano games in which a number is picked or denoted as a wild number that may 35 
be used to  fill any number or letter on a beano card.  36 
8.  Winner -take-all round.   "Winner -take-all round" means a beano game or series 37 
of beano games in which all the proceeds from the sale of the cards for that round are 38 
paid to participants as prizes during that r ound.  39 
9.  Registrant.  "Registrant" means a person or organization registered with the 40 
Gambling Control Unit to hold, conduct or operate beano games for which a license is not 41 
required.  42

 Page 752 - 128LR2175(04) -1

the Gambling Control Unit and must be credited to the General Fund.  14 
§313 -D.  Registration exceptions  15 
Notwithstanding section 312, subsection 1 and section 313 -E, and subject to the 16 
conditions set out in this section, the following organizations may conduct beano without 17 
a license or without registering with the Gambling Control  Unit.  18 
1.  Senior organizations.  Clubs, groups or organizations composed of individuals at 19 
least 90% of whom are 62 years of age or older when beano is conducted for their own 20 
entertainment and not for profit.  21 
2.  Campgrounds.  A campground licensed under  Title 22, section 2492 or a 22 
campground operated by the State Government or the Federal Government when:  23 
A.  Beano is offered exclusively to campground patrons and guests of campground 24 
patrons;  25 
B.  A prize awarded to a winner of a beano game does not excee d a value of $25 for 26 
any one game; and  27 
C.  Proceeds from fees charged to campground patrons and their guests to participate 28 
in a beano game are used only to pay for prizes awarded to players and to cover the 29 
actual costs incurred to operate the games.  30 
3.  Resort hotels. A bona fide resort hotel, which includes a full -service hotel facility 31 
and offers leisure and recreational activities to its patrons, such as tennis, golf or 32 
horseback riding, when:  33 
A.  Beano is offered exclusively to resort hotel patrons an d their guests;  34 
B.  A prize awarded to a winner of a beano game does not exceed a value of $25 for 35 
any one game; and  36 
C.  Proceeds from fees charged to resort hotel patrons and their guests to participate 37 
in a beano game are used only to pay for prizes awar ded to players and to cover the 38 
actual costs incurred to operate the games.  39

 Page 753 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  4.  Schools.  A school for children in kindergarten to grade 8 when:  1 
A.  Games are offered exclusively to students and faculty of the school and their 2 
families;  3 
B.  A prize awarded  to a winner of a beano game does not exceed a value of $25 for 4 
any one game; and  5 
C.  Proceeds from fees charged to participate in a beano game are used only to pay 6 
for prizes awarded to players, to support a parent -teacher organization associated 7 
with the  school and to cover the actual costs incurred to operate the games.  8 
Notwithstanding section 319, persons under the age of 16 may take part in a game of 9 
beano conducted under subsection 2, 3 or 4.  10 
§313 -E.  Prize limits  11 
A single prize awarded for a game of beano may not exceed $400 in value and the 12 
total amount of prizes awarded on any one occasion may not exceed $1,400 in value 13 
except that once per calendar year on one occasion a registrant may award up to $2,000 in 14 
total prizes.  This section does not appl y to high -stakes beano conducted in accordance 15 
with section 314 -A. 16

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 755 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §315 -A.  Limited dual beano registration  1 
The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may issue a limited dual beano 2 
license  registration  to 2 organizations eligible for a regular license  registr ation  to conduct 3 
a game of beano.  A limited dual beano license  registration  permits 2 organizations to 4 
conduct beano jointly on the same date and at the same location.  An organization may 5 
only conduct beano under the authority of a dual license  registrat ion on 2 occasions 6 
during a calendar year.  The following provisions apply to licensure  registration  under 7 
this section.  8 
1.  Application.  The 2 organizations wishing to conduct beano jointly shall submit 9 
an application to the Chief of the State Police  Gam bling Control Unit  in a manner 10 
prescribed by the chief  unit. 11 
2.  Lead registrant.  One organization must be identified as the lead applicant  12 
registrant  and acknowledge responsibility for any violation of the laws or rules governing 13 
beano committed during t he conduct of the game.  14 
3.  Disposition of revenue.  Revenue received from the conduct of the game must be 15 
divided in equal amounts between both organizations.  Each organization shall file a 16 
disposition of funds report as if that organization had conducte d beano independently.  17 
4.  Registration fee.  The license  registration  fee for a limited dual beano license is 18 
$12. 19 
5.  Sealed tickets.  A limited dual beano license  registration  does not authorize the 20 
licensed  registered  organizations to sell sealed ticke ts jointly.  21 
6.  Application of other laws.  Unless otherwise provided by this section, the 22 
provisions of this chapter and rules adopted in accordance with this chapter apply to 23 
beano games conducted under a limited dual beano license  registration . 24

amended to read:  26 
§316.  Evidence  27 
The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may require such evidence as 28 
the chief  unit may determine necessary to satisfy the chief  unit that an a pplicant or 29 
organization licensed or registered  to conduct beano conforms to the restrictions and 30 
other provisions of this chapter. Charters, organizational papers, bylaws or other such 31 
written orders of founding that outline or otherwise explain the purpo se for which 32 
organizations were founded must, upon request, be forwarded to the Chief of the State 33 
Police  Gambling Control Unit .  The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may 34 
require such evidence as the chief  unit may determine necessary regard ing the conduct of 35 
beano by a licensee or registrant  to determine compliance with this chapter.  36

Sec. JJJJJ -20.  17 MRSA §317 -A, as amended by PL 2001, c. 342, §2, is further 14 
amended to read:  15 
§317 -A.  Investigations; actions on licenses and registrations  16 
1.  Gambling Control Unit.   The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  17 
may:  18 
A.  Investigate all aspects of this chapter incl uding the direct and indirect ownership 19 
or control of any licenses , registrations  or commercial beano hall permits;  20 
B.  Suspend, revoke or refuse to issue a license or registration , after notice of the 21 
opportunity for a hearing, if the applicant, applicant 's agent or employee, licensee , 22 
registrant  or the licensee's or registrant's  agent or employee violates a provision of 23 
this chapter or Title 17 -A, chapter 39 or fails to meet the statutory requirements for 24 
licensure or registration  pursuant to this chapter ; 25 
C.  Immediately suspend or revoke a license or registration  if there is probable cause 26 
to believe that the licensee or the licensee's agent or employee or the registrant or the 27 
registrant's agent or employee  violated a provision of Title 17 -A, chapter 39 ; 28 
D.  Suspend or revoke a commercial beano hall permit, after notice of the opportunity 29 
for hearing, if a permittee or permittee's employee commits murder or a Class A, B or 30 
C crime or violates a provision of this chapter or Title 17 -A, chapter 15, 29, 37 or 39;  31 
E.  Immediately suspend or revoke a commercial beano hall permit if there is 32 
probable cause to believe that the permittee or the permittee's employee committed 33 
murder or a Class A, B or C crime or violated a provision of Title 17 -A, chapter 15, 34 
29, 37 or 39; and  35 
F.  Issue a subpoena in the name of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  in 36 
accordance with Title 5, section 9060, except that this authority applies to any stage 37 
of an investigation under this chapter and is not limited to an adjudicatory hearing.  38 
This authority may not be used in the absence of reasonable cause to believe a 39 
violation has occurred.  If a witness refuses to obey a subpoena or to give any 40 
evidence relevant to proper inquiry by the chief  unit, the Attorney General may 41 
petitio n the Superior Court in the county where the refusal occurred to find the 42 
witness in contempt.  The Attorney General shall cause to be served on that witness 43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 757 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  an order requiring the witness to appear before the Superior Court to show cause why 1 
the witness s hould not be adjudged in contempt.  The court shall, in a summary 2 
manner, hear the evidence and, if it is such as to warrant the court in doing so, punish 3 
that witness in the same manner and to the same extent as for contempt committed 4 
before the Superior Court or with reference to the process of the Superior Court.  5 
2.  Action after notice and opportunity for hearing.   The Chief of the State Police  6 
Gambling Control Unit  shall notify the applicant, licensee , registrant  or permittee in 7 
writing, before a licen se, registration  or permit is denied, suspended or revoked pursuant 8 
to subsection 1, paragraph B or D, of the intended denial or commencement date of the 9 
suspension or revocation, which may not be made any sooner than 96 hours after the 10 
licensee's , registr ant's or permittee's receipt of the notice, of the duration of the 11 
suspension or revocation and of the right to a hearing pursuant to this subsection.  The 12 
applicant, licensee , registrant  or permittee has the right to request a hearing before the 13 
Commissio ner of Public Safety or the commissioner's designee.  Upon the applicant's, 14 
licensee's , registrant's  or permittee's request for a hearing, the Commissioner of Public 15 
Safety shall provide a hearing.  The hearing must comply with the Maine Administrative 16 
Procedure Act.  The purpose of the hearing is to determine whether a preponderance of 17 
the evidence establishes that the applicant, applicant's agent or employee, licensee or 18 
licensee's agent or employee or registrant or registrant's agent or employee  violated  a 19 
provision of this chapter or Title 17 -A, chapter 39 or the permittee or the permittee's 20 
employee committed murder or a Class A, B or C crime or violated a provision of this 21 
chapter or Title 17 -A, chapter 15, 29, 37 or 39.  A request for a hearing may no t be made 22 
any later than 10 days after the applicant, licensee , registrant  or permittee is notified of 23 
the proposed denial, suspension or revocation.  The suspension or revocation action must 24 
be stayed pending the hearing; the hearing may not be held any l ater than 30 days after 25 
the date the commissioner  director  receives the request unless otherwise agreed by the 26 
parties or continued upon request of a party for cause shown.  27 
3.  Immediate suspension or revocation.   A licensee whose license or permittee 28 
whos e permit is immediately suspended or revoked by the Chief of the State Police  29 
Gambling Control Unit  pursuant to subsection 1, paragraph C or E must be notified in 30 
writing of the duration of the suspension or revocation and the licensee's or the 31 
permittee's  right to request a hearing before the Commissioner of Public Safety or the 32 
commissioner's designee.  Upon the licensee's or permittee's request for a hearing, the 33 
Commissioner of Public Safety shall provide a hearing.  The hearing must comply with 34 
the Mai ne Administrative Procedure Act.  The purpose of the hearing is to determine 35 
whether a preponderance of the evidence establishes that the licensee or the licensee's 36 
agent or employee or registrant or registrant's agent or employee  violated a provision of 37 
Title 17 -A, chapter 39 or the permittee or the permittee's employee committed murder or 38 
a Class A, B or C crime or violated a provision of Title 17 -A, chapter 15, 29, 37 or 39.  A 39 
request for a hearing may not be made any later than 48 hours after the licen see or 40 
permittee is notified of the suspension or revocation.  A hearing may not be held any later 41 
than 10 days after the date the commissioner receives the request.  42

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 758 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §319.  Persons under 16 years of age  1 
Persons under 16 years of age are not permitted to take part in the conduct of, nor 2 
participate in, the game of "beano" or "bingo," nor may persons under 16 years of age be 3 
admitted to the pla ying area unless accompanied by a parent, guardian or other 4 
responsible person.  5 
"Beano" or "bingo" games licensed or registered under this chapter may not be 6 
conducted unless some person at least 18 years of age, who has been a member in good 7 
standing of t he licensee or registrant for at least 2 years, exercises exclusive control of 8 
each game played.  9 
A license or registration for the conduct of "beano" or "bingo" may not be issued to 10 
any firm, association, corporation or group composed wholly or primarily o f persons 11 
under 16 years of age.  12 
Sec. JJJJJ -22.  17 MRSA §320, sub -§§1 and 2, as enacted by PL 2003, c. 452, 13 
Pt. I, §8 and affected by Pt. X, §2, are amended to read:  14 
1.  Liquor prohibited.   A licensee or registrant  may not conduct "beano" or "bingo" 15 
in the same room where liquor is sold, served or consumed during the period of one hour 16 
before the conduct of the games.  17 
2.  Disorderly persons prohibited.   A licensee or registrant  may not permit a 18 
disorderly person to enter or remain within the room or area w here "beano" or "bingo" 19 
games are being conducted.  20

Sec. JJJJJ -26.  17 MRSA §325, as repealed and replaced by PL 2003, c. 452, Pt. 16

§325.  Penalties  18 
1.  Violation of chapter or rules; general penalty.   Except as othe rwise specifically 19 
provided, a person, firm, association or corporation that violates a provision of this 20 
chapter or a rule of the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  prescribed by 21 
authority of this chapter commits a civil violation for which a  fine of not more than 22 
$1,000 may be adjudged.  23 
2.  Commercial beano hall violations.   A person, corporation, partnership or 24 
unincorporated association that rents or leases a building or facilities to hold, conduct or 25 
operate "beano" or "bingo" commits a Cl ass E crime if that person, corporation, 26 
partnership or unincorporated association:  27 
A.  Rents or leases a building or facilities to hold, conduct or operate a "beano" or 28 
"bingo" game without a commercial beano hall permit issued by the Chief of the 29 
State P olice  Gambling Control Unit ; or 30 
B.  Violates a provision of this chapter or a rule adopted by the Chief of the State 31 
Police  Gambling Control Unit  pursuant to this chapter.  32 
Violation of this subsection is a strict liability crime as defined in Title 17 -A, section 34, 33 
subsection 4 -A. 34 
Sec. JJJJJ -27.  17 MRSA §326, as amended by PL 1997, c. 684, §4, is further 35 
amended to read:  36 
§326.  Proceeds  37 
1-A.  Payment of proceeds.   An organization licensed or registered  to operate beano 38 
or bingo and Lucky 7 games in conjun ction with beano or bingo may use the proceeds or 39 
part of the proceeds to:  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 760 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  A.  Pay salaries, wages or remuneration to any person directly involved in operating 1 
beano, bingo or Lucky 7 games;  2 
B.  Defray the expenses or part of the expenses that further the purpose for which the 3 
organization is formed except that proceeds may not be:  4

(2)  Paid directly to organization members except as specifically allowed in this 7

C.  Defray the expenses or part of the expenses of a member, auxiliary member, 9 
officer or employee of the organization for a serious illness, injury or casualty loss if 10

division within the Bureau of State Police  Gambling Control Unit . 12

person who would receive the proceeds has adequate means of financial 23

benefits.  25

as allowed by subsection 1 -A must file with the Chief of the State Police  Gambling 27 
Control Unit , at least quarterly,  a form for the disposition of funds prescribed by the 28 
Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  detailing all payments made.  Every 29 
statement on the form must be made under oath by an officer of the organization.  30 
2.  Rules.  The rules adopted pursuan t to section 317 must contain standards 31 
governing payments made under this section.  Payments under subsection 1 -A, paragraph 32 
A may not exceed 20% of the revenue generated by the games and the rules must limit 33 
payments to reasonable compensation, taking in to account the nature of the services 34 
rendered, comparable wage rates, the size of the organization and other revenues, the size 35 
of the games and the revenue generated by the games.  The Chief of the State Police  36 
Gambling Control Unit  may disallow any exce ssive payment of proceeds, may suspend 37 
an organization's license or registration  for excessive payment of proceeds and may 38 
condition the restoration of an organization's license or registration  on the repayment of 39 
an excessive payment of proceeds by the or ganization.  40

Sec. KKKKK -8.  17 MRSA §1831, sub -§5, as amended by PL 2011, c. 420, Pt. 10 
A, §11, is further amended to read:  11 
5.  Game of chance.  "Game of chance" means a game, contest, scheme or device in 12 
which:  13 
A.  A person sta kes or risks something of value for the opportunity to win something 14 
of value;  15 
B.  The rules of operation or play require an event the result of which is determined 16 
by chance, outside the control of the contestant or participant; and  17 
C.  Chance enters as a n element that influences the outcome in a manner that cannot 18 
be eliminated through the application of skill.  19 
For the purposes of this subsection, "an event the result of which is determined by 20 
chance" includes but is not limited to a shuffle of a deck of cards, a roll of a die or dice or 21 
a random drawing or generation of an object that may include, but is not limited to, a 22 
card, a die, a number or simulations of any of these. A shuffle of a deck of cards, a roll of 23 
a die, a random drawing or generation of an object or some other event the result of 24 
which is determined by chance that is employed to determine impartially the initial order 25 
of play in a game, contest, scheme or device does not alone make a game, contest, 26 
scheme or device a game of chance.  For purposes of this chapter, beano, bingo , a savings 27 
promotion raffle  and table games as defined in Title 8, section 1001, subsection 43 -A are 28 
not games of chance.  29

A, §2, is amended to r ead: 31

chance.  34

Sec. KKKKK -15.  17 MRSA §1832, as enacted by PL 2009, c. 487, Pt. A, §2, is 17 
amended  to read:  18 
§1832.  Licenses  19 
1.  License or registration required.  Except as provided in section 1833, a  A 20 
person, firm, corporation, association or organization may not hold, conduct or operate a 21 
game of chance without a license issued by or, as applicable , without registering with  the 22 
Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  in accordance with this section.  A 23 
license is not required when a game of chance constitutes social gambling.  24 
2.  Eligible organizations; licenses.  Notwithstanding other provi sions of law, the 25 
Chief of the State Police  The Gambling Control Unit  may issue a license to operate a 26 
game of chance  card game and certain tournament games  to an organization that submits 27 
a completed application as described in subsection 5 and has been f ounded, chartered or 28 
organized in this State for a period of not less than 2 consecutive years prior to applying 29 
for a license and is:  30 
A.  An agricultural society;  31 
B.  A bona fide nonprofit charitable, educational, political, civic, recreational, 32 
fraternal , patriotic or religious organization;  33 
C.  A volunteer fire department; or  34 
D.  An auxiliary of any of the organizations in paragraphs A to C.  35 
2-A.  Registration.  The Gambling Control Unit may accept a registration from an 36 
eligible organization described i n subsection 2 and other persons as specifically provided 37 
under section 1835 -A, section 1836, subsection 4 -B and section 1837 -A to conduct games 38 
of chance, raffles and charitable cribbage tournaments.  An eligible organization or 39 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 765 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  person seeking to register  to conduct a game of chance, raffle or charitable cribbage 1 
tournament shall register in the manner prescribed by the Gambling Control Unit and 2 
shall maintain records and reports in the same manner as described under section 1839, 3 
except that disposition o f funds reports are not required to be submitted to the Gambling 4 
Control Unit but must be maintained in the same manner as other records.  5 
3.  Must be 18 years of age.   The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  6 
may not accept a registration to co nduct a game of chance, a raffle or certain tournament 7 
games or accept  an application from or issue a license for card games and certain 8 
tournament games  under this section to a person or  representative of an eligible 9 
organization who is not 18 years of ag e or older.  10 
4.  Municipal approval required.   An eligible organization described in subsection 11 
2 applying for a license to conduct a card game of chance  and tournament games 12 
requiring a license  shall obtain written approval from the local governing authori ty where 13 
the game of chance  is to be operated or conducted.  This written approval must be 14 
submitted with the application to the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  as 15 
described in subsection 5.  16 
5.  Application.   An eligible organization descri bed in subsection 2 wishing  seeking 17 
to obtain a license  to operate or  conduct a card game of chance  or certain tournament 18 
games requiring a license  shall submit an application to the Chief of the State Police  19 
Gambling Control Unit .  The application must be  in a form provided by the Chief of the 20 
State Police  Gambling Control Unit  and must be signed by a duly authorized officer of 21 
the eligible organization. The application must include the full name and address of the 22 
organization, a full description of the card game of chance  or tournament game , the 23 
location where the card game or tournament game  is to be conducted and any other 24 
information determined necessary by the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  25 
for the issuance of a license to operate a card game of chance  or certain tournament 26 
games , including but not limited to membership lists, bylaws and documentation showing 27 
the organization's nonprofit status or charitable designation.  28 
6.  Multiple licenses.   The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Co ntrol Unit  may 29 
issue more than one license or registration  to conduct or operate a game of chance  30 
governed by this chapter  simultaneously to an eligible organization described in 31 
subsection 2.  Each game of chance  governed by this chapter  must have a separ ate 32 
license, the nature of which must be specified on the license.  33 
7.  Agricultural fairs.   Notwithstanding any provision in this chapter to the contrary, 34 
in addition to games of chance, the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may 35 
issue a licen se accept a registration  to conduct or operate games of chance known as 36 
"penny falls" or "quarter falls" at any agricultural fair, as long as the net revenue from 37 
those games is retained by the licensed  registered  agricultural society.  38 
8.  Electronic video  machines.   The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  39 
may issue a game of chance  license to operate an electronic video machine to any eligible 40 
organization described in subsection 2.  41 
A.  An electronic video machine licensed under this section ma y only be operated for 42 
the exclusive benefit of the licensee, except that up to 50% of the gross proceeds 43 
from the operation of the machine may be paid to the distributor as a rental fee and 44 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 766 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  for service and repair of the machine. Notwithstanding other prov isions of this 1 
chapter, a licensee may rent an electronic video machine from a distributor.  2 
B.  No more than 5 electronic video machines may be operated on the licensee's 3 
premises.  A separate games of chance license is required for the operation of each 4 
electronic video machine.  5 
C.  A licensee may operate an electronic video machine only on the licensee's 6 
premises.  7 
D.  Two or more licensees may not share the use of any premises for the operation of 8 
electronic video machines.  9 
E.  A distributor or employee o f the distributor may not be a member of the licensed 10 
organization.  11 
F.  An electronic video machine licensed under this subsection may not be operated 12 
in a manner that meets the definition of illegal gambling machine as described in 13 
Title 17 -A, section 952 , subsection 5 -A. 14

§1834.  Fees  17 
1.  Original application fee.   The original application for a license to operate a game 18 
of chance must be accompanied by a fee of $ 7.50. This is not a fee for a license and is not 19 
refundable.  20

chance is $15 for each  week computed on a Monday to Sunday basis or for a portion of a 23 
week.  The fee for a license issued for a calendar month is $60 and the fee for licenses 24 
issued for a calendar year is $700.  25

cards as provided in subsection 4, licenses  Registration  to conduct any authorized game 28

§1835.  Conduct card games  22

games  of chance  a card game . 24

for the entry fee are limited to a $10 daily entry fee and no more than 60 players at 29 
any one time at any one location.  30

calendar year and contributes 100% of the gross revenue from those games of chance  32

(3)  Twenty -five cents per card received.  36

 Page 768 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  2.  Games conducted by members and bartenders of licensee only.   A card game 1 
of chance  licensed pursuant to this chapter must be operated and conducted for the 2 
exclusive benefit of the licensee and must be operated and conducted only by duly 3 
authorized members of the licensee or by persons employed by the licensee as bartenders, 4 
except that n onmembers employed by the licensee as bartenders may not operate or 5 
conduct any card game of chance  permitted under subsection 5, paragraph B.  The 6 
requirements of this subsection do not apply to any agricultural society licensed to 7 
operate a card game of chance . 8 
3.  Games conducted at agricultural fair by members of the agricultural society 9 
or a bona fide nonprofit.  Games of chance  Card games  operated and conducted solely 10 
by members of an agricultural society or card games of chance  operated and conducted  11 
by members of bona fide nonprofit organizations on the grounds of the agricultural 12 
society and during the annual fair of the agricultural society may use cash, tickets, tokens 13 
or other devices approved by the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Uni t by rule.  14 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, the tickets, tokens or other devices 15 
approved by the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  must be unique to the 16 
agricultural society and may be in denominations of 25¢, 50¢ or $1.  The tickets, tokens 17 
or devices approved by the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may be sold 18 
and redeemed only by a person who has been a member or active volunteer of the 19 
agricultural society for at least 2 fair seasons.  The agricultural so ciety has the burden of 20 
proof for demonstrating the qualification of members or active volunteers.  21 
An agricultural society that uses tokens shall provide records and reports as required by 22 
section 1839.  23 
4.  Persons under 18 years of age.  Except as provide d in this subsection, a  A 24 
licensee, game owner or operator may not permit a person under 18 years of age to take 25 
part in a card game of chance, and a person under 18 years of age may not sell chances, 26 
except in relation to charitable, religious or recogniz ed youth associations .  27 
Notwithstanding any rule to the contrary, upon receiving an application on a form 28 
provided by the Chief of the State Police and a determination by the chief that a game of 29 
chance licensed to be conducted at a festival -style event is  designed to attract players 30 
under 18 years of age and awards a nonmonetary prize valued at less than $10 for every 31 
chance played, the chief may permit:  32 
A.  Persons under 18 years of age to conduct or operate the game of chance; and  33 
B.  Persons under 18 ye ars of age to play the game of chance without being 34 
accompanied by an adult.  35 
Nothing in this subsection permits games of chance to be operated without a license.  36 
5.  Location.   A license issued pursuant to this section must specify the location 37 
where the o rganization may operate the licensed card game of chance .  A licensee may 38 
not operate card games of chance  in more than one location at the same time.  39 
A.  An agricultural society or a bona fide nonprofit organization may operate a card 40 
game of chance  on th e grounds of an agricultural society and during the annual fair of 41 
the agricultural society.  42

 Page 769 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  B.  No more than one licensee may operate a card game of chance  at a time on the 1 
same premises.  In any room where a licensed card game of chance  is being 2 
conducte d, there must be at least one member of the licensee present in that room for 3 
every 2 nonmembers who are present.  That member must have been a member of the 4 
licensee for at least one year.  A member of the licensee, either directly or through 5 
another memb er or guest, may not stake or risk something of value in the licensee's 6 
card game of chance  unless the member has been a member of the licensee for at 7 
least 14 days not including the day of admission into membership.  8 
A bona fide nonprofit organization may operate a licensed card game of chance  to which 9 
the general public has access once every 3 months for a period not to exceed 3 10 
consecutive days.  The licensed card game of chance  may be operated at any location 11 
described in the license and may be conducted  only by members of the licensee.  This 12 
subsection does not apply to raffles conducted in accordance with section 1837.  13 
6.  Door prizes.   Distribution of tickets to an event upon which appear details 14 
concerning any prize to be given away as a result of a d rawing is a game of chance within 15 
the meaning of this chapter; a distribution of tickets containing only the words "Door 16 
Prize," without further description, is excluded from the provisions of this chapter, as 17 
long as no promotional materials or presentati ons, written or oral, describe the door prize.  18 
7.  "Donation" not to provide an exclusion.  The word "donation" printed on a 19 
ticket does not exclude the sponsoring organization from complying with this chapter.  20 
8.  Wager limit exception.  Notwithstanding s ubsection 1, an organization that is 21 
licensed to conduct games of chance in accordance with this chapter is permitted to 22 
accept wagers up to $50 per hand for a poker run.  The organization must inform the 23 
Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  30 days in advance of the date when the 24 
organization intends to conduct a poker run with an increased wager limit.  An 25 
organization is limited to 2 poker run events per calendar year in which wagers up to $50 26 
per hand are permitted.  For the purposes of this subsection, "poker run" means a game of 27 
chance using playing cards that requires a player to travel from one geographic location 28 
to another in order to play the game.  29

4-A.  Exception for super cribbage tournament.  Notwithstanding any provision of 3 
this section to the contrary, the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may 4 
issue up to 3 licenses per year for the conduct of a super cribbage tournament.  For the 5 
purposes of this subsection, "cribbage" means a card game that uses a board and pegs to 6 
keep score and of which the c haracteristic feature is a crib into which players discard 7 
cards from their dealt hand to create a crib of 4 cards unseen by other players that will be 8 
ultimately part of the dealer's hand.  The license fee for a super cribbage tournament is 9

for a tournament game by this section except as follows.  11

than 3 years.  16

licensee.  20

4-B.  Charitable cribbage tournament.  The Gambling Control Unit shall accept a 28 
registration for a cribbage tournament to be conduct ed as prescribed by this subsection.  29 
For the purposes of this section, "cribbage" means a card game that uses a board and pegs 30

a process of elimination.  A cribbage tournament may extend beyond a calendar day.  A 34

the operator:  36

Sec. KKKKK -25.  17 MRSA §1837 -A is enacted to read:  22 
§1837 -A.  Raffles  23 
1.  Registration required.  Unless otherwise specified by this section, a person or 24 
organization may not conduct a raffle without registering with the Gambling Control 25 
Unit.  26 
2.  Raffle with a prize of $1,000 or less.  A person or organization is not required to 27 
register with the Gambling Control Unit to conduct a raffle in which the total value of the 28 
prize offered to the holder of the winning chance does not exceed $1,000.  If the raffle is 29 
conducted in a manner in which there are multiple winnin g chances, the total value of all 30 
prizes offered may not exceed a value of $1,000.  31 
3.  Raffle with a noncash prize of $1,001 to $10,000.  A person or organization may 32 
conduct a raffle in which the total value of the prize offered to the winning chance is 33 
greater than $1,001 and does not exceed $10,000 upon the acceptance of a registration by 34 
the Gambling Control Unit.  The Gambling Control Unit may not accept a registration for 35 
a raffle under this subsection unless the registration states a verifiable chari table purpose 36 
for which the proceeds of the raffle are dedicated to benefit.  If the raffle is conducted in a 37 
manner in which there are multiple winning chances, the total value of all prizes offered 38 
may not exceed a value of $10,000.  A prize offered for a raffle conducted under this 39 
subsection may not be in the form of cash and may not be exchanged for cash.  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 774 - 128LR2175(04) -1

in which the total value of the prize offered to the winning chance does not exceed 3 
$75,000 upon the acceptance of a registration by the Gambling Control Unit.  The 4 
registration must state a verifiable charitable purpose for which th e proceeds of the raffle 5 
are dedicated to benefit.  If the raffle is conducted in a manner in which there are multiple 6 
winning chances, the total value of all prizes offered may not exceed a value of $75,000.  7

may not be exchanged for cash.  An eligible organization may not conduct more than one 9 
raffle under this subsection in a 12 -month period.  10

chances or tickets may not be sold by a person under 18 years of age, except for raffles 12

Sec. KKKKK -27.  17 MRSA §1839, as enacted by PL 2009, c. 487, Pt. A, §2, is 9 
amended to read:  10 
§1839.  Records and r eports  11 
1.  Records required.   Each licensee or registrant  shall keep a record of all financial 12 
transactions involving games of chance  operated under each license granted to the 13 
licensee  this chapter .  The treasurer of the licensee or another officer design ated by the 14 
treasurer is responsible for maintaining those records.   The records must include an exact 15 
account of all gross revenue from the games, an itemization of all allowable expenses, 16 
including, but not limited to, the cost of prizes, printing, licen ses and administration, and 17 
the disposition of all proceeds, including, but not limited to, all gifts, grants and payments 18 
to any person, firm, corporation, association or organization for any purpose whatsoever.  19 
All financial records involving games of chance  operated under this chapter  must be 20 
separate and distinguishable from other records of the organization.  Revenue from more 21 
than one game of chance  operated under this chapter  may be entered into one account.  22 
2.  Records required for licensee or regi strant employing tokens.   If a licensee or 23 
registrant  employs tokens to account for revenue from games of chance  operated under 24 
this chapter  and if the licensee or registrant  maintains direct control over the sale and 25 
redemption of the tokens and keeps acc urate records of all tokens used, then the chief  26 
Gambling Control Unit  may by rule alter or reduce the record -keeping requirements of 27 
subsection 1 to the extent that a licensee's  the use of tokens renders those records 28 
unnecessary for adequate control of t he licensee's or registrant's  games.  29 
3.  Disposition of funds reports.   Within 10 business days after the last day of any 30 
period during which a licensed game of chance  under this chapter  is conducted with other 31 
than an annual license or within 10 business days after the end of each calendar month 32 
during which a licensed game of chance is conducted with an annual license , the licensee 33 
shall file with the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  a disposition of funds 34 
form prescribed and furnished by t he Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit , 35 
detailing for the period the total receipts and expenditures of the game and the disposition 36 
of funds.  Every statement must be made under oath by an officer of the licensee or by the 37 
member in charge of the conduct of the game.  A registrant who conducts games under 38 
this chapter shall maintain records of disposition of funds, which must be made available 39 
to the Gambling Control Unit upon request.  40 
4.  Disposition of funds reports from registrant using toke ns.  If tokens are 41 
employed to account for revenue from games of chance  operated under this chapter , then 42 
the licensee  registrant  shall maintain a  report of the number of tokens sold, the number 43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 776 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  redeemed and the disposition of funds from the proceeds of sa le in addition to such other 1 
information as the chief  Gambling Control Unit  may require under subsection 3.  2 
5.  Records maintained for 3 years.   Every licensee or registrant  that has conducted 3 
a game of chance  under this chapter  shall maintain and keep for  a period of 3 years 4 
reports as may be necessary to substantiate the records and reports required by this 5 
section or by the rules adopted under this chapter.  6 
6.  Location.  All records maintained by a licensee or registrant  pursuant to this 7 
section and purs uant to the rules adopted under this chapter must be kept and maintained 8 
on the premises where the game of chance  has been conducted or at the primary business 9 
office of the licensee or registrant , which must be designated by the licensee in the license 10 
application or the registrant in the registration .  These records must be open to inspection 11 
by the Chief of the State Police or the chief's representative  Gambling Control Unit , and a 12 
licensee or registrant  may not refuse the Chief of the State Police or th e chief's 13 
representative  Gambling Control Unit  permission to inspect or audit the records.  Refusal 14 
to permit inspection or audit of the records does not constitute a crime under this chapter 15 
but constitutes grounds for revocation of license or registratio n. 16 
Sec. KKKKK -28.  17 MRSA §1840, as enacted by PL 2009, c. 487, Pt. A, §2, is 17 
amended to read:  18 
§1840.  Distributors; records and reports  19 
1.  Printers licensed.   A printer in the State may not print materials to be used in the 20 
conduct of a licensed game of  chance unless licensed by the Chief of the State Police.  A 21 
printer licensed under this section may act as a distributor without having to be licensed 22 
as a distributor as long as neither the printer nor anyone on the printer's behalf acts as a 23 
seller for services connected with a game of chance outside of the confines of the printer's 24 
premises described in that printer's license.  If that printer or someone else acts as a seller 25 
for the printer's services in connection with a game of chance outside of the premises 26 
described on that printer's license, either that printer or any person or persons acting on 27 
that printer's behalf must be licensed as a distributor under subsection 2.  28 
The applicant for a printer's license, or, if the applicant is a firm, corporat ion, association 29 
or other organization, its resident manager, superintendent or official representative shall 30 
file an application with the Chief of the State Police on a form provided by the Chief of 31 
the State Police.  The Chief of the State Police shall f urnish to each applicant a current 32 
copy of this chapter and the rules adopted under section 1843 and to each licensee a copy 33 
of any changes or additions to this chapter and the rules adopted under section 1843.  34 
2.  Distributors licensed.   A distributor may  not sell, lease, market or otherwise 35 
distribute gambling apparatus or implements unless licensed by the Chief of the State 36 
Police  Gambling Control Unit , except that a license is not required for the sale, marketing 37 
or distribution of raffle tickets when t he holder of the winning chance receives something 38 
of value worth less than $10,000.  39 
A nonresident manufacturer or distributor of gambling apparatus or implements doing 40 
business in the State must have an agent in this State who is licensed as a distributor .  A 41 
distributor may not sell, market or otherwise distribute gambling apparatus or implements 42 
to a person or organization, except to persons or eligible  organizations described under 43

subsection 1  1837 -A.  A distributor may not lease or loan or othe rwise distribute free of 4

game of chance  under this chapter , except that a distributor may lease gambling apparatus 6 
or implements to an agricultural society licensed  regist ered to operate games of chance on 7 
the grounds of the agricultural society and during the annual fair of the agricultural 8 
society as long as the distributor does not charge the agricultural society an amount in 9 
excess of 50% of the gross revenue from any licensed  game of chance  conducted under 10 
this chapter . 11 
A licensee or registrant  shall acquire gambling apparatus and implements from a 12 
distributor licensed under this section, unless the gambling apparatus or implements are 13 
printed, manufactured or construct ed by the licensed organization.  At no time may any 14

section 1843 and to each licensee a copy of any changes or additions to this chapter and 22 
the rules adopted under section 1843.  23 
3.  Sales agreements.  A distributor shall forward to the Chief of the State Police  24 
Gambling Control Unit , prior to delivery of any gambling machine to the purchaser, a 25 
copy of all sales agreements, sales contracts or any other agreemen ts involving the sale of 26 
any gambling machine.  The terms of the sales contract must include, but are not limited 27 
to, the name of seller, name of purchaser, address of seller, address of purchaser, 28 
description of the gambling machine including serial numbe r and model name and 29 
number, total sale price, any arrangement or terms for payments and the date of final 30 
payment.  31 
Any change, modification or alteration of these agreements must be reported to the Chief 32 
of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  by the pu rchaser within 6 days of the change, 33 
modification or alteration.  34 
4.  Service agreements.  With the sale of any gambling machine involving a service 35 
agreement, the distributor shall forward to the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control 36 
Unit a copy of the  agreement prior to delivery of the machine.  The terms of the service 37 
agreements must include, but are not limited to, the name of seller, name of purchaser, 38 
address of seller, address of purchaser, description of machine to be serviced including 39 
serial n umber and model name and number and all prices and payments for that service.  40 
Any change, modification or alteration of the agreement must be reported to the Chief of 41 
the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  by the purchaser within 6 days of the change, 42 
modi fication or alteration.  43 
5.  Agricultural societies; lease agreements.   When a gambling apparatus or 44 
implement is leased as provided in subsection 2 to an agricultural society, the distributor 45

 Page 778 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  shall forward to the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit a copy of the lease 1 
agreement prior to delivery of the gambling apparatus or implement.  The terms of the 2 
lease must include, but are not limited to, the name of the lessor; address of the lessor; 3 
name of the lessee; address of the lessee; description  of the gambling apparatus or 4 
implement; serial number, model name or number of the gambling apparatus or 5 
implement; and all prices and payments for the lease.  Each lease must be for a specific 6 
period of time no longer than the duration of the annual fair  of that lessee, and each 7 
gambling apparatus must have its own separate lease.  Gambling apparatus or implements 8 
leased under this section:  9 
A.  May be operated only for the exclusive benefit of the agricultural society, except 10 
that the agricultural society  may pay a distributor up to 50% of gross gaming revenue 11 
in accordance with subsection 2; and  12

6.  Reports.   At the end of each calendar month, a distributor or printer  shall file with 14 
the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  a report indicating:  15 
A.  The names and addresses of all persons or organizations to which the distributor 16 
or printer  has distributed equipment and the dates of the distribution;  17 
B.  A description of the equipment distribu ted, including serial number and model 18 
name and number; and  19 
C.  The quantities of any equipment distributed.  20 
7.  Retention and inspection of records.  A distributor or printer  shall maintain and 21 
keep for a period of 3 years, on the premises of the distribut or or printer , any records that 22 
may be necessary to substantiate the reports required by this section or by the rules 23 
adopted under this chapter.  The records must be open to inspection, and a licensee or 24 
registrant  may not refuse the Chief of the State Po lice or the chief's representative  25 
Gambling Control Unit  permission to inspect or audit the records.  Refusal to permit 26 
inspection or audit of the records does not constitute a crime under this chapter but 27 
constitutes grounds for revocation of license or registration . 28 
8.  Reports generally.   The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  shall 29 
require from any licensed printer or  distributor, or from any organization authorized to 30 
operate a game of chance  under this chapter , whatever reports determined  necessary by 31 
the chief  unit for the purpose of the administration and enforcement of this chapter.  32

used in the absence of reasonable cause to believe a violation has occurred.  If a 37 
witness refuses to obey a subpoena or to give any evidence relevant to proper inquiry 38 
by the chief  unit, the Attorney General may petition the Superior Court in the county 39 
where the refusal occurred to find the witness in contempt.  The Attorney General 40 
shall cause to be served on that witness an order requiring the witness to appear 41 
before the Superior Court to show cause why the witness should not be adjudged  in 42

Gambling Control Unit  shall notify the applicant , registrant  or licensee in writing, before 24 
a license or registration  is denied, suspended or revoked pursuant to subsection 3, 25 
paragraph B, of the intended den ial or commencement date of the suspension or 26 
revocation, which may not be made any sooner than 96 hours after the licensee's or 27 
registrant's  receipt of the notice, of the duration of the suspension or revocation and of the 28 
right to a hearing pursuant to t his subsection.  The applicant or, licensee , person 29 
registering or registrant  has the right to request a hearing before the Commissioner of 30 
Public Safety or the commissioner's designee.  Upon the applicant's or licensee's  request 31 
for a hearing, the Commiss ioner of Public Safety shall provide a hearing.  The hearing 32 
must comply with the Maine Administrative Procedure Act.  The purpose of the hearing 33 
is to determine whether a preponderance of the evidence establishes that the applicant, 34 
person registering,  applicant's or registering person's  agent or employee or the licensee , 35 
registrant  or licensee's or registrant's  agent or employee violated a provision of this 36 
chapter or Title 17 -A, chapter 39.  A request for a hearing may not be made any later than 37 
10 days after the applicant or, licensee , person registering or registrant  is notified of the 38 
proposed denial, suspension or revocation.  The suspension or revocation must be stayed 39 
pending the hearing; the hearing may not be held any later than 30 days after the date the 40 
commissioner receives the request unless otherwise agreed by the parties or continued 41 
upon request of a party for cause shown.  42

registration  is immediately suspended  or revoked by the Chief of the State Police  44 
Gambling Control Unit  pursuant to subsection 3, paragraph C must be notified in writing 45 
of the duration of the suspension or revocation and the licensee's or registrant's  right to 46

amended to read:  25 
§1843.  Rules  26 
The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may adopt routine technical 27 
rules pursuant to Title 5, ch apter 375, subchapter 2 -A necessary for the administration 28 
and enforcement of this chapter and for the licensing , registration , conduct and operation 29 
of games of chance  governed by this chapter .  The Chief of the State Police  Gambling 30 
Control Unit  may regu late, supervise and exercise general control over the operation of 31 
such games. In establishing such rules, the Chief of the State Police must  Gambling 32 
Control Unit shall , in addition to the standards set forth in other provisions of this 33 
chapter, set forth  conduct, conditions and activity considered undesirable, including:  34 
1.  Fraud.  The practice of any fraud or deception upon a participant in a game of 35 
chance  governed by this chapter ; 36 
2.  Unsafe premises.  The conduct of a game of chance  governed by this ch apter  in or 37 
at premises that may be unsafe due to fire hazard or other such conditions;  38 
3.  Advertising and solicitation.  Advertising that is obscene or solicitation on a 39 
public way of persons to participate in a game of chance  governed by this chapter ; 40 
4.  Organized crime.  Infiltration of organized crime into the operation of games of 41 
chance  governed by this chapter  or into the printing or distributing of gambling materials;  42

the operation of games of chance  governed by this chapter  not in accordance with this 4

§3, is further amended to read:  18 
The Commissioner of Public Safet y shall adopt, in accordance with requirements of 19 
the Maine Administrative Procedure Act, a schedule of fees for the examination of all 20 
plans for construction, reconstruction or repairs submitted to the Department of Public 21 
Safety. The fee schedule for new  construction or new use is 5¢ per square foot for 22 
occupied spaces and 2¢ per square foot for bulk storage occupancies, except that a fee for 23 
review of a plan for new construction by a public school may not exceed $450.  The fee 24 
schedule for reconstruction , repairs or renovations is based on the cost of the project and 25 
may not exceed $450, except as provided in section 2450 -A.  The fee schedule for new 26 
construction, reconstruction, repairs or renovations is 1.5/10 of 1% of the cost to 27 
construct or reconstru ct the portion of the project that is subject to State Fire Marshal 28 
review.   Except for projects reviewed by a municipality pursuant to section 2448 -A, the 29 
fees must be credited to a special revenue account to defray expenses in carrying out this 30 
section.  Any balance of the fees may not lapse, but must be carried forward as a 31 
continuing account to be expended for the same purpose in the following fiscal years.  32 
For projects reviewed by a municipality that include occupied spaces, a 1¢ fee per square 33 
foot m ust be remitted to the Department of Public Safety and a 4¢ fee per square foot 34 
must be paid to the municipality.  35

commissioner's regular duties.  The compensation and expense of th e deputy 6 
commissioner is paid from any available funds appropriated for the use of the bureau of 7 
which the deputy commissioner is chief.   The commissioner may appoint and employ the 8 
deputy commissioners,  bureau chiefs and the assistant to the commissioner  director of 9 
legislative affairs  to be under the commissioner's immediate supervision, direction and 10 
control, and to serve at the commissioner's pleasure and perform such duties as the 11 
commissioner may prescribe, except as otherwise provided by law.  In the  absence of the 12 
commissioner, the commissioner, or the Governor if the commissioner is unable, may 13 
appoint one of the deputy commissioners to act on behalf of the commissioner.   In 14 
addition, the commissioner may appoint an associate commissioner for admini strative 15 
services who is not subject to the Civil Service Law and who serves at the pleasure of the 16 
commissioner.  17 
Sec. QQQQQ -3.  Department of Administrative and Financial Services; 18 
Bureau of General Services; reorganization.  The Commissioner of Administr ative 19 
and Financial Services shall review those provisions of the Maine Revised Statutes 20 
governing the Bureau of General Services and, based upon that review, develop and 21 
submit a bill for introduction to the Second Regular Session of the 128th Legislature  that 22 
reorganizes in statute the functions and activities of the Bureau of General Services and 23 
proposes any necessary budgetary changes.  Prior to submitting a bill, the commissioner 24 
may organize the activities and functions of the Bureau of General Servi ces in a manner 25 
the commissioner determines is most effective and efficient.  26
