Sec. RRRRR -1.  7 MRSA §402 -B is enacted to read:  28 
§402 -B.  Annual General Fund transfer  29

PART SSSSS  33 
Sec. SSSSS -1.  34-A MRSA §1406 is enacted to read:  34 
§1406.  Authority to review financial records of counties as those records relate to 35 
corrections  36 
1.  County jail records.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary, 37 
the commissioner may inspect, review and take custody of records of the counties as 38 
those records relate to the funding and operation of the county jails.  Upon the request of 39 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 786 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  the commissioner, a county jail within 15 days of the request shall supply complete and 1 
accurate information.  The commissioner shall work with the jails to assist them in 2 
achieving compliance with the requirements of this subsection.  The commissioner shall 3 
enforce the standards of this subsection by imposition of monetary penalties pursuant to 4 
policies and procedures under section 1208 -B, subsection 1, paragraph B.  This 5 
subsection must be liberally construed to effect the purpose of this section.  6 
2.  Violation.  A state government agency or local government entity whose officer 7 
or employee violates subsection 1 commits a civil violation for which a fine of not more 8 
than $5,000 may be adjudged.  9 
3.  Appeal.  If the commissioner is aggri eved by a refusal or denial to inspect or copy 10 
a record or a failure to allow the inspection or copying of a record under this section, the 11 
commissioner may appeal the refusal, denial or failure within 30 calendar days of the 12 
receipt of the written notice of refusal, denial or failure to the Superior Court for the 13 
county where the person refusing, failing or denying the inspection or copying resides or 14 
the agency employing that person has its principal office.  The agency or official shall file 15 
a statement of position explaining the basis for denial within 14 calendar days of service 16 
of the appeal.  If a court, after a review, and taking of testimony and other evidence as 17 
determined necessary, determines the refusal, denial or failure was not for just and pr oper 18 
cause, the court shall enter an order for disclosure.  Appeals may be advanced on the 19 
docket and receive priority over other cases when the court determines that the interests 20 
of justice so require.  21 
4.  Proceedings not exclusive.  The proceedings auth orized by this section are not 22 
exclusive of any other civil remedy provided by law.  23 
5.  Attorney's fees.   In an appeal under subsection 3 or another civil proceeding, the 24 
court may award reasonable attorney's fees and litigation expenses to the substantia lly 25 
prevailing plaintiff who appealed pursuant to subsection 3 or in another civil proceeding 26 
if the court determines that the illegal action was committed in bad faith.  Attorney's fees 27 
and litigation costs may not be awarded to or against a federally rec ognized Indian tribe.  28 
6.  Subpoena power.  The commissioner may, in connection with the performance of 29 
the commissioner's duties, apply to the Superior Court for a subpoena to compel the 30 
attendance of witnesses and the production of books, papers, records and documents of 31 
individuals, firms, associations and corporations and all officers, boards, commissions 32 
and departments of county government.  The court, before issuing the subpoena, shall 33 
provide adequate opportunity for the commissioner and the party ag ainst whom the 34 
subpoena is requested to be heard.  The court may issue the subpoena only on a showing 35 
by the commissioner and specific findings of fact by the court that the attendance of the 36 
witness or the production of the books, papers, records or docum ents is reasonably 37 
necessary to carry out specific duties of the commissioner that are related to the 38 
operations and finances of the county jails and that the commissioner has made 39 
reasonable efforts to secure the attendance or the books, papers, records o r documents 40 
without recourse to compulsory process.  41 
Sec. SSSSS -2.  Report.  By February 15, 2018, the Department of Corrections 42 
shall submit a report to the Joint Standing Committee on Appropriations and Financial 43 
Affairs on plans to restructure the fundin g and operation of county jails and correctional 44 
facilities and prisoner population and capacity.  45

Sec. UUUUU -4.  30-A MRSA §6205, as enacted by PL 2005, c. 266, §2, is 3

§6205.  Eligibility; intergovernmental cooperation  5 
In accordance with the request for proposals issued by the department under section 6 
6209, an eligible applicant may apply for a planning grant , a capital grant  or a 7 
cooperative services grant from the fund.  In order to be eligible for a planning grant , a 8 
capital grant  or a cooperative services grant, an eligible applicant must demonstrate in its 9 
application that the project for which it seeks a grant will be undertaken in cooperation 10 
with one or more municipalities, counties or regional government subdivisions.  11 
An eligible applicant may  contract with nongovernmental organizations and 12 
individuals for the purpose of carrying out projects supported by the fund.  13 
In applying for a cooperative services grant or a capital grant , an eligible applicant 14 
must specify the type of qualifying project for which assistance is sought and how the 15 
project will reduce demand for property tax revenues.  16

Sec. VVVVV -6.  20-A MRSA c. 123 is enacted to read:  13 
CHAPTER 123  14 
SCHOOL MANAGEMENT AN D LEADERSHIP CENTERS  15 
§3801.  General provisions  16 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this chapt er, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 17 
following terms have the following meanings.  18 
A.  "Municipality" means a city, town or organized plantation.  19 
B.  "School management and leadership center" means a multiservice agency 20 
established and operated e xclusively for the purposes of developing, managing and 21 
providing services or programs to 2 or more members pursuant to section 3802, 22 
subsection 2 and may include associate members pursuant to section 3802, subsection 23 
3.  A "school management and leadershi p center" is a political subdivision pursuant 24 
to section 3802, subsection 7.  25 
2.  Establishment.  A school administrative unit as described in section 3802, 26 
subsection 2 may become a member of a school management and leadership center 27 
through an interlocal agreement pursuant to Title 30 -A, chapter 115 and the agreement 28 
may include associate members as described in section 3802, subsection 3.  29 
3.  Interlocal agreement.  An interlocal agreement establishing a school 30 
management and leadership center must include  the structure and governance of the 31 
school management and leadership center and its functions, programs and services.  32 
A.  An interlocal agreement must include the specifications required pursuant to Title 33 
30-A, section 2203, subsection 2 and a description  of: 34 
(1)  The school management and leadership center board composition, election or 35 
appointment of officers, board member terms and method of voting;  36 
(2)  An approval process for a new school administrative unit to join the school 37 
management and leadershi p center;  38 
(3)  An approval process for an existing member to transfer to another school 39 
management and leadership center;  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 792 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (4)  The process for determining the sharing of costs for and the assessments of 1 
or payments to the school management and leadership c enter;  2 
(5)  The budget process that requires a school management and leadership center 3 
budget be adopted by a date established in order to meet local school 4 
administrative unit budget deadlines.  The budget process must include a 5 
contingency plan for a bud get failure and must be in the cost center summary 6 
budget format pursuant to section 1485;  7 
(6)  The process for a balanced budget as required by section 3802, subsection 10 8 
and the method of determining the return of any excess funds to the members of 9 
the school management and leadership center; and  10 
(7)  The process for the disposition of indebtedness and property including by 11 
sale or lease, transferred to or from or administered by the school management 12 
and leadership center.  13 
B.  An interlocal agreement ma y include but is not limited to a description of the 14 
following:  15 
(1)  The approval process for the formation of a school management and 16 
leadership center;  17 
(2)  Any associate members, the process for including associate members and 18 
their roles in the school management and leadership center;  19 
(3)  The process to authorize the school management and leadership center to 20 
borrow funds for school construction purposes including bonds and notes;  21 
(4)  The process to approve the purchase or lease of buildings or land b y the 22 
school management and leadership center;  23 
(5)  The process by which a school management and leadership center may 24 
establish, maintain and expend funds from a reserve fund or contingency fund;  25 
(6)  The process of hiring an executive director for the sc hool management and 26 
leadership center; and  27 
(7)  A transition plan to move authorized programs and services from a member 28 
to the school management and leadership center.  29 
An interlocal agreement cannot transfer a school administrative unit's responsibility f or 30 
providing the opportunity of a free public education to each of its students or a free, 31 
appropriate education to each of its students with a disability as required by this Title or 32 
by federal law.  33 
4.  Duties of school management and leadership center.  A school management 34 
and leadership center's functions, programs and services may include but are not limited 35 
to the following:  36 
A.  Accounting, payroll and financial management services and procurement;  37 
B.  Transportation, transportation routing and vehicle  maintenance;  38 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 793 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  C.  Reporting functions;  1 
D.  Special education programs and administration;  2 
E.  Gifted and talented programs and administration;  3 
F.  Alternative education programs and administration;  4 
G.  Substitute teachers and staff augmentation;  5 
H.  Techno logy and technology support;  6 
I.  Food service planning and purchasing;  7 
J.  Energy management and facilities maintenance;  8 
K.  Regional school leadership academies;  9 
L.  Staff training and professional development;  10 
M.  Shared educational programs or staff;  11 
N.  Shared support service programs;  12 
O.  Educational programs such as summer school, extended school year, tutoring, 13 
advanced placement and other programs that serve students and improve student 14 
achievement;  15 
P.  Shared extracurricular or cocurricular program s; and  16 
Q.  Superintendent services.  17 
§3802.  School management and leadership center authorized  18 
A school management and leadership center shall provide administrative and 19 
education functions in accordance with this chapter and shall function as an extension  of 20 
the member school administrative units and associate members of the school management 21 
and leadership center.  A member school administrative unit of the school management 22 
and leadership center cannot transfer the responsibility for providing the opport unity of a 23 
free public education to each of its students or a free, appropriate education to each of its 24 
students with a disability as required by this Title or by federal law.  25 
1.  Geographic boundaries.  The commissioner shall determine 9 to 12 geographic  26 
areas for the establishment of each school management and leadership center.  27 
Membership in a particular school management and leadership center does not require the 28 
member to be physically located in the school management and leadership center's 29 
geograph ic boundary.  30 
2.  Members.  Members in a school management and leadership center must be 31 
determined by interlocal agreement pursuant to Title 30 -A, chapter 115 and may include 32 
the following types of school administrative units:  33 
A.  Community school district s pursuant to chapter 105;  34 
B.  Municipal school units pursuant to chapter 111;  35 
C.  Regional school units pursuant to chapter 103 -A; 36 
D.  School administrative districts pursuant to chapter 103; and  37 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 794 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  E.  Schools established on tribal lands pursuant to Title 3 0, chapter 601.  1 
3.  Associate members.  Associate members for a school management and leadership 2 
center may include the following through a contractual agreement or memorandum of 3 
understanding with the members of the school management and leadership center : 4 
A.  Career and technical education regions pursuant to chapter 313, subchapter 4;  5 
B.  Public charter schools as defined in chapter 112;  6 
C.  Providers of child development services pursuant to chapter 303;  7 
D.  Magnet schools pursuant to chapters 312 and 3 12-A; 8 
E.  The Maine Educational Center for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing and the 9 
Governor Baxter School for the Deaf pursuant to chapter 304;  10 
F.  Providers of education in the unorganized territory pursuant to chapter 119; or  11 
G.  Municipalities and counties  pursuant to Title 30 -A. 12 
4.  Provision of services to or from other public entities or nonprofit entities.   A 13 
school management and leadership center may provide services to or purchase services 14 
from other types of political subdivisions, public entities o r nonprofit organizations or 15 
associations.  16 
5.  Purchase of services from another school management and leadership center.  17 
A member of a school management and leadership center may purchase services from 18 
another school management and leadership center if n ot provided by the member’s school 19 
management and leadership center.  20 
6.  Validation.  A school management and leadership center authorized and 21 
organized under this chapter is validated, confirmed, approved and declared legal in all 22 
respects, notwithstandin g any defect or irregularity that may have occurred in the 23 
organization of the school management and leadership center or in the selection of the 24 
board of that school management and leadership center.  25 
7.  Political subdivision.  A school management and lea dership center is a political 26 
subdivision within the meaning of Title 5, section 19002, subsection 6 and a quasi - 27 
municipal corporation within the meaning of Title 30 -A, section 5701, and all the 28 
provisions of those sections apply to it. Notwithstanding Tit le 30 -A, section 2203, 29 
subsection 8, paragraph B, the members of a school management and leadership center 30 
may delegate eminent domain power to the school management and leadership center by 31 
agreement. A school management and leadership center is considere d a tax -exempt 32 
governmental entity for the purposes of Title 36, section 1760, subsection 2.  33 
8.  Executive director.  A school management and leadership center shall employ an 34 
executive director, and the interlocal agreement under section 3801, subsection 3 must 35 
specify that the executive director shall administer, in compliance with this chapter, the 36 
provisions of the interlocal agreement in the school management and leadership center.  37 
9.  Personnel.  The executive director of a school management and leade rship center 38 
may employ a chief financial officer and may employ additional staff necessary to 39 
administer the functions assigned to the school management and leadership center 40 
through the provisions of the interlocal agreement under section 3801, subsectio n 3. 41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 795 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  10.  Balanced budget.  A school management and leadership center must have a 1 
balanced budget and return excess funds to the members as prescribed by the interlocal 2 
agreement under section 3801, subsection 3.  3 
11.  Authority to borrow, expend and accept  funds.  A school management and 4 
leadership center may:  5 
A.  Borrow funds in anticipation of a member’s payment of its share of the school 6 
management and leadership center budget. Such borrowing:  7 
(1)  Must be repaid within one year; and  8 
(2)  May not at any time exceed 3/4 of the school management and leadership 9 
center's annual approved budget;  10 
B.  Expend available funds to pay debt service, security and maintenance costs; and  11 
C.  Accept and expend funds from state, federal and other sources and expend those 12 
funds on behalf of the members.  13 
12.  Bonding authority.  A school management and leadership center may issue 14 
bonds and notes for school construction purposes. For purposes of this section, "school 15 
construction purposes" includes minor capital costs relatin g to maintenance of a school's 16 
physical plant. The school management and leadership center board shall decide whether 17 
the issuance of bonds or notes by the school management and leadership center for school 18 
construction purposes is necessary. The board sha ll determine whether the issuance of 19 
bonds or notes is authorized, and, if so, the board shall issue the bonds or notes and 20 
administer the proceeds of, and the payment of principal of and interest on, those bonds 21 
or notes after issuance. A school managemen t and leadership center may issue bonds and 22 
notes for school construction purposes only under the provisions of the interlocal 23 
agreement under section 3801, subsection 3.  24 
13.  Withdrawal from school management and leadership center.  If a single 25 
school adm inistrative unit applies to withdraw, it must demonstrate to the commissioner 26 
that as a result of the school administrative unit's withdrawing that there will be no 27 
increase in costs or decrease in student programs and services for the withdrawing school 28 
administrative unit and for any of the remaining member school administrative units of 29 
the school management and leadership center.  30 
14.  Dissolution of school management and leadership center.  A school 31 
management and leadership center may not be dissolved unless it applies to the 32 
commissioner for approval and:  33 
A.  All member school administrative units apply to transfer to another school 34 
management and leadership center; or  35 
B.  If all the member school administrative units of a school management and 36 
leaders hip center apply to dissolve the school management and leadership center, 37 
they demonstrate to the commissioner that there will be no increase in costs or 38 
decrease in student programs and services for any of the member school 39 
administrative units of the sch ool management and leadership center.  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 796 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  15.  Reporting requirements.  A school management and leadership center must 1 
meet state and federal reporting requirements on behalf of each member school 2 
administrative unit.  3 
§3803.  Oversight  4 
The commissioner shall p rovide oversight of the school management and leadership 5 
centers, and this oversight must include the following.  6 
1.  Data collection; monitoring.  The commissioner or the commissioner's designee 7 
is responsible for collecting, analyzing and reporting data f rom school management and 8 
leadership centers. The commissioner or the commissioner's designee shall monitor the 9 
performance and legal compliance of the school management and leadership centers, 10 
including collecting and analyzing data to support ongoing eva luation of the school 11 
management and leadership centers.  12 
2.  Notification of unsatisfactory performance or compliance.  If a school 13 
management and leadership center’s performance or legal compliance appears 14 
unsatisfactory, the commissioner shall promptly p rovide written notice to the school 15 
management and leadership center and its members of perceived problems and provide 16 
reasonable opportunity for the school management and leadership center to remedy the 17 
problems.  The school management and leadership cent er shall provide the commissioner 18 
a corrective action plan to remedy the problems.  19 
§3804.  Audit  20 
A school management and leadership center shall adhere to generally accepted 21 
accounting principles and shall annually engage an external auditor to do an indep endent 22 
audit of the school management and leadership center's finances. The school management 23 
and leadership center shall submit the audit to its members and to the department. The 24 
audit must be conducted in the same manner as a school administrative unit audit in 25 
accordance with chapter 221, subchapter 2.  26 
§3805.  Application for and approval of a school management and leadership center  27 
1.  Application.  The commissioner shall establish an application process under this 28 
chapter for the formation of a school  management and leadership center.  The application 29 
must be in a form and contain such information as required by the commissioner, 30 
including, but not limited to:  31 
A.  The identification of the school administrative units that are applying to form the 32 
schoo l management and leadership center;  33 
B.  The specified structure and governance of the school management and leadership 34 
center and its purposes, functions, programs and services;  35 
C.  How any savings resulting from the formation of the school management and 36 
leadership center will be used; and  37 
D.  A copy of the proposed interlocal agreement pursuant to section 3801, subsection 38 
3. 39 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 797 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  2.  Commissioner’s approval.  If an application under this section contains the 1 
information required pursuant to subsection 1, the c ommissioner shall notify each school 2 
administrative unit participating in the school management and leadership center that, 3 
pending voter approval as set forth in subsection 3, the school management and 4 
leadership center is approved pursuant to this chapte r. The commissioner shall keep a 5 
register of school management and leadership centers that have been approved pursuant 6 
to this chapter.  7

management and leadership center pursuant to subsection 2, the school management and 9

agreement pursuant to section 3801, subsection 3, paragraph B, subparagraph (1).  11 
§3806.  Direct state funding of a school  management and leadership center  12 
A school management and leadership center receives direct state funds for start -up 13 
costs in accordance with section 15689, subsection 9.  A school management and 14 
leadership center that provides to members at least 2 differ ent services covering a total of 15 
at least 2 different categories as specified in section 15683 -C, subsection 2 must receive 16 
annual support for 55% of the executive director’s salary and benefits, an accounting and 17 
payroll system and a student information s ystem.  18 
The school administrative units that are members of a school management and 19 
leadership center must receive state funds in accordance with section 15683 -C. 20 
§3807.  Regional school leadership academies  21 
A regional school leadership academy is a profess ional development consortium that 22 
combines state and local programs and resources, including the preparation, licensure, 23 
certification, professional development and training for educational leadership, into a 24 
coherent system that can significantly improve the recruitment and preparation of 25 
prospective candidates for school principals and other school leadership positions, as well 26 
as the induction, mentoring and retention of principals and school leaders during the first 27 
2 years of employment in their school  leadership positions.  The mission of an academy 28 
may be to enhance the quality of the preservice and in -service staff training programs for 29 
school principals and other school leadership positions, to improve the distribution, 30 
supply and quality of school leadership personnel in underserved school administrative 31 
units in the State and to develop appropriate professional development pathways at 32 
participating schools in the academy.  To fulfill its mission, the academy may work in 33 
coordination with educationa l leadership mentors and coaches, with high -performing 34 
educational leaders and with educator preparation programs and statewide education 35 
associations.  36

Sec. VVVVV -10.  20-A MRSA §15683 -C is enacted to read:  24 
§15683 -C.  School management and leadership center members; calculation of 25 
school management and leadership cen ter administration allocation and 26 
state contribution  27 
Beginning with fiscal year 2018 -19, this section applies to school administrative units 28 
that are members of school management and leadership centers pursuant to chapter 123.  29 
1.  Calculation of school man agement and leadership center per -pupil rate.  The 30 
commissioner shall calculate a per -pupil amount for school management and leadership 31 
center administration.  The per -pupil amount for school management and leadership 32 
center administration is based on the actual General Fund expenditures for school 33 
administrative units with 2,500 students or more for the functions of school boards, 34 
elections and central offices, as defined in the State's accounting handbook for local 35 
school systems for the most recent year available, excluding expenditures for 36 
administrative technology -related software and less miscellaneous revenues from other 37 
local governments, divided by the average of October and April enrollment counts for 38 
that fiscal year and adjusted by appropriate tr ends in the Consumer Price Index or other 39 
comparable index.  40 
2.  Categories of services of school management and leadership center.  The 41 
following are the categories of services that a school administrative unit that is a member 42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 800 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  of a school management and l eadership center pursuant to chapter 123 may purchase for 1 
funding purposes under section 3806.  2 
A.  Category 1, instructional services, includes the following services:  3 
(1)  Special education programs and administration;  4 
(2)  Gifted and talented programs an d administration;  5 
(3)  Alternative education programs and administration;  6 
(4)  Shared educational programs or staff; and  7 
(5)  Educational programs such as summer school, extended school year, 8 
tutoring, advanced placement and other programs that serve stude nts and improve 9 
student achievement.  10 
B.  Category 2, education support services, includes the following services:  11 
(1)  Substitute teachers and staff augmentation;  12 
(2)  Technology and technology support;  13 
(3)  Staff training and professional development;  14 
(4)  Regional school leadership academies;  15 
(5)  Shared support services programs; and  16 
(6)  Shared extracurricular or cocurricular programs.  17 
C.  Category 3, central office services, includes the following services:  18 
(1)  Accounting, payroll, financial managemen t services and procurement;  19 
(2)  Reporting functions;  20 
(3)  Food service planning and purchasing; and  21 
(4)  Superintendent services.  22 
D.  Category 4, facilities and transportation system services, includes the following 23 
services:  24 
(1)  Transportation, transpor tation routing and vehicle maintenance; and  25 
(2)  Energy management and facilities maintenance.  26 
3.  Eligibility for school management and leadership center allocation.  The 27 
commissioner shall determine that a school administrative unit is eligible for a sch ool 28 
management and leadership center allocation if according to its school management and 29 
leadership center interlocal agreement pursuant to section 3801, subsection 3, the school 30 
administrative unit purchases at least 2 different services covering a total  of at least 2 31 
different categories from the school management and leadership center as specified in 32 
subsection 2.  33

rate in subsection 1 multiplied by the school administrative unit's subsidizable pupil count 4 
for October 1st of the most recent calendar year pr ior to the year of funding.  The state 5 
contribution for each school administrative unit's school management and leadership 6 
center allocation is the allocation multiplied by the school administrative unit's state share 7 
percentage pursuant to section 15672, subsection 31, not to exceed 70% and not less than 8 
30%.  9

Sec. YYYYY -1.  20-A MRSA §5205, sub -§12 is enacted to read:  16 
12.  Secondary student open enrollment period.  Each April 1st to May 1st is an 17 
annual open enrollment period for a secondary student to request a transfer pursuant to 18 
subsection 6 to a public high school in another school administrative uni t in the next 19 
school year.  During the open enrollment period, the student’s resident school 20

is considered a resident of the school administrative unit to which the student transferred.  24 
PART ZZZZZ  25 
Sec. ZZZZZ -1.  20-A MRSA §7303 is enacted to re ad: 26 
§7303.  Education savings accounts  27 
The department shall, in accordance with this section, establish education savings 28 
accounts, referred to in this section as "savings accounts," for children with disabilities.  29 
Savings accounts may be used by the pare nts or legal guardians of such children for 30 
educational purposes in accordance with this section.  31 
1.  Establish savings accounts.   The department by rule shall establish an application 32 
process for a parent or legal guardian of a child with disabilities to request the 33 
establishment of a savings account.  An application requesting establishment of a savings 34 
account must be submitted to the department no later than January 1st preceding the 35 
school year in which the account will be used.  The department may est ablish a savings 36 
account only upon a demonstration by the parent or legal guardian that the child has been 37 
enrolled in a public school for at least one school year and that an individualized 38 
education program has been determined for the child and only if t he parent or legal 39 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 803 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  guardian signs an agreement with the department pursuant to subsection 2.  The 1 
establishment of savings accounts must be limited to no more than 100 students.  2 
2.  Written agreement.  The department and the parent or legal guardian of a c hild 3 
for whom a savings account will be established must sign an agreement that the parent or 4 
legal guardian will not enroll the child in a public school or charter school for the school 5 
year in which the education savings account is established and that t he parent or legal 6 
guardian will use a portion of the education savings account funds allocated annually to 7 
provide an education for the child in a manner consistent with the system of learning 8 
results established in section 6209.  9 
3.  Renewal, rollover and  closure.   The department may annually renew a savings 10 
account and deposit funds into the account in accordance with subsection 5 if, in 11 
accordance with rules adopted by the department, the parent or legal guardian 12 
demonstrates that the child continues to have and follow an individualized education 13 
program and has completed a national norm -referenced achievement test and has had a 14 
review and acceptance of the child's progress by an identified individual who holds a 15 
current teacher's certificate from the Sta te.  Unspent funds in a savings account that is 16 
renewed remain in the savings account and may be used in accordance with subsection 5, 17 
except that no more than 75% of the funds deposited in any year may be carried forward.  18 
Any unspent amount that is in ex cess of 75% of the funds deposited in that year must be 19 
transferred at the end of the fiscal year to the State Controller for handling in accordance 20 
with subsection 6.  If the requirements of this subsection are not met, the department shall 21 
close the savi ngs account and transfer all funds in the savings account to the State 22 
Controller, who shall handle the funds as provided in subsection 6.  23 
4.  Maintenance of fund for postsecondary education.  After a child for whom a 24 
savings account has been created gradu ates from high school, no further funds may be 25 
deposited in the account, but to the extent there are funds remaining in the account, the 26 
fund, at the request of the child or the parent or legal guardian of the child, must, in 27 
accordance with rules adopted by the department, remain open and available to help fund 28 
a postsecondary course of education for the child.  If the child does not enroll in such a 29 
course within 4 years after graduating from high school, the department shall close the 30 
savings account and  transfer all funds in the savings account to the State Controller, who 31 
shall handle the funds as provided in subsection 6.  32 
5.  Funding and oversight.   The department shall administer and oversee savings 33 
accounts as follows.  34 
A.  Each year the department sh all deposit into each active savings account 90% of 35 
the state subsidy that is attributable to the child for whom the savings account is 36 
established and that would otherwise have been provided to the child's school 37 
administrative unit under chapter 606 -B.  The department shall also direct that school 38 
administrative unit to deposit into the savings account 90% of the school 39 
administrative unit's required contribution to the unit's total cost of education 40 
attributable to that child.  The department shall calcu late these amounts and shall 41 
allocate the state funds to the extent possible in a manner consistent with the 42 
schedules applicable to state subsidy payments pursuant to section 15689 -B. 43 
B.  The department and the State Controller may each separately receive  up to 1/5 of 44 
that 10% of the state subsidy attributable to a child for whom a savings account is 45 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 804 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  established that is not deposited in the savings account.  Funds received under this 1 
paragraph may be used to pay the costs of administering this section.  2 
C.  The parent or legal guardian of a child may expend funds in a savings account 3 
only through the use of a debit card and may use funds in the account to pay for only 4 
the following educational expenses:  5 
(1)  Tuition and fees at a private primary or secondary  school;  6 
(2)  Textbooks;  7 
(3)  Educational therapies;  8 
(4)  Tutoring by a certified teacher or education technician II or III;  9 
(5)  Online classes;  10 
(6)  Test fees;  11 
(7)  Services provided by a public school, including access to or enrollment in 12 
extracurricula r activities or individual classes;  13 
(8)  Reimbursement of fees for transportation related to the child's education, for 14 
which receipts must be provided to the department, up to $500 in any one year;  15 
(9)  Consumable materials relating to educational activit ies, up to $100 in any 16 
one year; and  17 
(10)  Tuition and fees at a university or vocational school recognized by the 18 
department in accordance with rules adopted by the department or accredited by a 19 
regional accrediting agency approved or recognized by the Un ited States 20 
Department of Education.  21 
A parent or legal guardian of a child may not use funds in a savings account to pay in 22 
cash for any educational expense under this paragraph.  23 
D.  On a quarterly basis the department shall review all expenditures from sa vings 24 
accounts to ensure that they are in accordance with the requirements of this 25 
subsection and rules adopted under this section.  If at any time the department finds 26 
that expenditures from a savings account are not in accordance with the requirements 27 
of this subsection or rules adopted under this section, the department shall notify the 28 
parent or legal guardian of the child of the apparent misuse of funds and shall freeze 29 
the account so that no further expenditures may be made.  If, after an opportunity for 30 
hearing, the department determines that there was no misuse of funds, it shall 31 
unfreeze the account.  If the department determined there was in fact a misuse of 32 
funds, the department shall direct the parent or legal guardian to repay within 30 days 33 
to the State the amount of misused funds.  All repaid funds must be transferred to the 34 
State Controller for handling in accordance with subsection 6.  If the parent or legal 35 
guardian does not repay the full amount of misused funds or file an appeal of the 36 
department’s decision within the 30 days, the department shall close the savings 37 
account and transfer all funds in the savings account to the State Controller for 38 
handling in accordance with subsection 6.  A decision by the department under this 39 
paragraph is a final agency action that may be appealed to the Superior Court by a 40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 805 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  parent or legal guardian within 30 days of the decision in accordance with the Maine 1 
Rules of Civil Procedure, Rule 80C.  2 
6.  Funds returned.  Any funds transferred out of or removed from  a savings account 3 
or paid to the State by the parent or legal guardian of a child under this section and 4 
received by the State Controller must be handled by the State Controller in accordance 5 
with this subsection.  The State Controller shall divide the fu nds in the same proportion as 6 
the funds are deposited in the savings account from the State and the school 7 
administrative unit pursuant to subsection 5 and return the portion attributable to the 8 
school administrative unit to that unit and transfer the rema inder to the unappropriated 9 
surplus of the General Fund.  10 
7.  Rules.   The department shall adopt rules necessary to implement this section.  11 
Rules adopted pursuant to this subsection are routine technical rules as defined in Title 5, 12 
chapter 375, subchapter  2-A. 13 
Sec. ZZZZZ -2.  20-A MRSA §15689, sub -§14 is enacted to read:  14 
14.  Adjustment for education savings accounts.   The commissioner shall reduce 15 
the state share of the total allocation to a school administrative unit in any year in which 16 
one or more educa tion savings accounts under section 7303 are established for children 17 
within that school administrative unit.  The amount of the reduction must equal the total 18 
state subsidy that is attributable to all children in that school administrative unit for whom 19 
education savings accounts have been established, as determined by the department 20 
pursuant to section 7303, subsection 5, paragraph A.  21

Sec. BBBBBB -3.  20-A MRSA §8301 -A, sub -§3, as amended by PL 2003, c. 16 
545, §1, is further amended to read:  17 
3.  Center.   "Center" means an administrative entity established pursuant to this 18 
chapter that provides career and technical education to secondary students and mid dle 19 
school level students .  Unless otherwise specifically provided for by this chapter, a center 20 
is governed, operated and administered by a single school administrative unit.  A center 21 
shall make its programs available to serve secondary students and midd le school level 22 
students  from school administrative units with which it is affiliated.  A center may 23 
include within its administrative structure career and technical education satellite 24 
programs operated by school administrative units with which it is affi liated.  25

Sec. DDDDDD -5.  26 MRSA §965, sub -§1-A is enacted to read:  30 
1-A.  Public education employees negotiation.  This subsection governs the 31 
negotiation of standard salary and standard benefits for public education employee s. 32 
A.  Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, solely for the negotiation of 33 
standard salary and standard benefits for public education employees, the State is 34 
considered the public employer and subject to all limitations and responsibilities 35 
provided in this chapter. It is the obligation of the State and the bargaining agent 36 
representing public education employees across the State to bargain collectively for 37 
standard salary and standard benefits for public education employees in accordance 38 
with this subsection.  For the purposes of this subsection, "collective bargaining" 39 
means the mutual obligation of the State and the bargaining agent representing public 40 
education employees:  41 
(1)  To meet at reasonable times;  42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 811 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (2)  To meet within 10 days after  receipt of written notice from the other party 1 
requesting a meeting for collective bargaining purposes, as long as the parties 2 
have not otherwise agreed in a prior written contract;  3 
(3)  To execute in writing any agreements arrived at.  The term of any su ch 4 
agreement is subject to negotiation but may not exceed 2 years;  5 
(4)  To participate in good faith in the mediation, fact -finding and arbitration 6 
procedures required by this section; and  7 
(5)  To confer and negotiate in good faith with respect to salary a nd benefits.  8 
B.  Any cost item related to this subsection is the financial responsibility of the State.  9 
The cost item must be based upon student -staff ratios as established under Title 20 -A, 10 
chapter 606 -B. 11 
A cost item related to this subsection must be su bmitted for inclusion in the 12 
Governor's next operating budget within 10 days after the date on which the 13 
agreement is ratified by the parties.  If the Legislature rejects any of the cost items 14 
related to this subsection submitted to the Legislature, all co st items related to this 15 
subsection must be returned to the parties for further bargaining.  16 
For purposes of this paragraph, "cost item" means any benefit acquired through 17 
collective bargaining the implementation of which requires an appropriation by the 18 
Legislature.  19 
C.  The organization representing the majority of public education employees is the 20 
bargaining agent to represent public education employees for the collective 21 
bargaining purposes of this subsection between the State and the organization.  The 22 
organization must provide to the State a demonstration of majority support of public 23 
education employees.  24 
D.  Aside from the negotiation of standard salary and standard benefits under this 25 
subsection, a public education employee remains the employee of the public 26 
employer.  27 
E.  All matters not specified in this subsection appropriate to collective bargaining 28 
must be negotiated pursuant to subsection 1 by the public employer and the 29 
bargaining agent determined under section 966.  30

a school administrative unit that:  32

that the school administrative unit will participate in collective bargaining under 34

address truancy.  The Department of Education shall review the regional work of 25

shall undertake a comprehensive attendance initiative, looking at a holistic approach to 28 
supportive services to c hildren to ensure they are attending school and receiving the 29 
necessary supports for positive educational outcomes.  The department shall report to the 30 
Joint Standing Committee on Education and Cultural Affairs on the status of this work by 31 
January 31, 201 8. 32

PART MMMMMM  12 
Sec. MMMMMM -1.  Criteria for opioid health home grant providers.  By 13 
October 1, 2017, the Department of Health and Human Services, referred to  in this Part as 14 
"the department," shall undertake a process to update the criteria for providers included in 15 
a request for proposals for an opioid health home grant.  A grant must provide evidence - 16 
based integrated medication -assisted treatment for patient s with opioid use disorder, 17 
when such services are provided by:  18 
1.  Primary care medical provider practices designated as patient -centered medical 19 
homes; or  20 
2.  Behavioral health agencies licensed by the Department of Health and Human 21 
Services.  22 
The departm ent shall establish by emergency rule pursuant to section 5 of this Part 23 
the revised criteria for qualification as an opioid health home and the amount of the grant 24 
provided to each qualified opioid health home.  25 
Sec. MMMMMM -2.  Funding.  The funding includ ed in Part A for this Part 26 
covers intensive outpatient treatment, intermediate treatment and long -term levels of care, 27 
which include screening, medication, behavioral health counseling and office visits for 28 
patients diagnosed with opioid use disorder.  29 
Sec. MMMMMM -3.  Funds may not be transferred.  Notwithstanding the 30 
Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 1585 or any other provision of law, funding 31 
provided in Part A for this Part may not be transferred to any other appropriation or 32 
subdivision of an appr opriation made by the Legislature.  33 
Sec. MMMMMM -4.  Funds may not lapse.  Notwithstanding the Maine 34 
Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 1589 or any other provision of law, any unencumbered 35 
balance of appropriations contained in Part A for this Part remaining  at the end of fiscal 36 
year 2017 -18 and fiscal year 2018 -19 may not lapse but must be carried forward to be 37 
used for the same purposes.  38

Beginning the pay week commencing closest to August 1, 2017, the salary schedules, 13 
grades and stipends for the Judicial Department employees in the administrative services 14

2019.  Beginning the pay week commencing closest to January 1, 2019, the salary 21 
schedules, grades and stipends for the Judicial Department employees in the 22 
administrative services bargaining unit, the supervisory services bargaining unit, the law 23 
enforcement bargaining unit and the professional services bargaining unit must be 24 
adjusted ac cording to the respective collective bargaining agreements. The salary 25 
schedules, grades and stipends must be adjusted consistent with the terms of any tentative 26 
agreements ratified prior to September 30, 2017.  27 
Sec. TTTTTT -3.  Other employees; similar and equitable treatment.  28 
Employees of the Judicial Department who are excluded from collective bargaining 29 
pursuant to the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 26, section 1282, subsection 5, paragraphs 30 
B, C, D, E, F and G must be given treatment similar and equitabl e on a pro rata basis to 31 
that given employees covered by the collective bargaining agreements.  32

ending June 30, 2018 and in the amount up to $2,657,895 for the fiscal year ending June 36

between the Judicial Department and the Maine State Employees Association for the 38 
administrative services bargaining unit, the supervisory services bargaining unit, the law 39 
enforcement bargaining unit and the professional services bargaining unit and for th e 40 
costs of those Judicial Department employees referred to in section 3, who are excluded 41 
from collective bargaining pursuant to the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 26, section 1282, 42

Revenue Funds account from licensing, registration and other fees of professions 18 
licensed, certified or registered within the Office of Professional and Occupational 19 
Regulation t o the Board of Complementary Health Care Providers for the initial costs for 20 
establishing a licensing requirement for individuals practicing midwifery in the State and 21 
shall provide an accounting of the source or sources of the working capital advance to t he 22 
State Controller. The commissioner shall provide a report to the State Controller of the 23 
transfers necessary to implement the working capital advance pursuant to this section.  24 
Sec. VVVVVV -2.  Repayment of working capital advance to Board of 25 
Complementar y Health Care Providers.  The Commissioner of Professional and 26 
Financial Regulation shall ensure that licensing and other fees for individuals practicing 27 
midwifery in the State collected by the Board of Complementary Health Care Providers 28 
are sufficient to  ensure repayment of the working capital advance provided in section 1 of 29 
this Part and that the working capital advance is repaid from those fees on or before June 30 
30, 2019.  The commissioner shall provide a report to the State Controller of the transfers  31 
necessary to repay the working capital advance pursuant to this section.  32

SUMMARY  8 
PART A  9 
 10 
This Part makes appropriations and allocations of funds for the 2018 -2019 biennium.  11 
PART B  12 
 13 
This Part makes appropriations and allocations of funds for approved reclassifications 14 
and range changes.  15 
PART C  16 
 17 
This Part does the following.  18 
1.  It establishes the Total Cost of Education from Kindergarten to Grade 12 for fiscal 19 
year 2017 -18, the state contribution and the annual target state share percentage.  20 
2.  It provides statutory changes to the Essen tial Programs and Services Funding Act 21 
for implementation in the 2017 -2018 school year.  22 
3.  It provides statutory changes to the Essential Programs and Services Funding Act 23 
for implementation in the 2018 -2019 school year.  24 
4.  It provides statutory changes for the funding and oversight of the Maine School 25 
for Marine Science, Technology, Transportation and Engineering.  26 
5.  It directs the Commissioner of Education to develop a plan for funding public 27 
education from kindergarten to grade 12.  The plan must be b ased on providing direct 28 
instruction and support for student learning and include the establishment of a system to 29 
measure and ensure accountability for the use of the state funds.  The new school funding 30 
formula must be presented to the Legislature for co nsideration no later than the 2019 - 31 
2020 school year.  32 
6.  It sets the effective dates for certain sections of this Part.  33 
PART D  34 
 35 
This Part eliminates, for tax years beginning in 2017 or after, the 3% income tax 36 
surcharge imposed on taxable income in excess of $200,000 and eliminates the Fund to 37 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 819 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  Advance Public Kindergarten to Grade 12 Education since the source of that fund is the 1 
3% income tax surcharge.  2 
PART G  3 
 4 
Under current law, the homestead property tax exemption for property tax years 5 
beginning on or af ter April 1, 2017 increased by $5,000 to $20,000 and the percentage of 6 
state reimbursement to municipalities for property taxes lost as a result of the exemption 7 
increased from 50% to 62.5%.  This Part eliminates the increase in the exemption and 8 
state rei mbursement amounts for property tax years beginning on or after April 1, 2017.  9 
PART I  10 
 11 
This Part phases out the business equipment tax reimbursement, or BETR, program 12 
and transitions property eligible for the BETR program as of April 1, 2018 into the 13 
busin ess equipment tax exemption, or BETE, program. Property located at a retail sales 14 
facility and used in a retail sales activity first put into service on or after April 1, 2018 15 
will no longer be eligible for either the BETR or BETE program. Such retail prop erty 16 
placed into service on or before April 1, 2018 that qualifies for the BETE program will no 17 
longer be eligible for exemption after 2027.  18 
PART L  19 
 20 
This Part provides that the Department of Administrative and Financial Services is 21 
responsible for computer  systems and applications used across multiple executive branch 22 
agencies.  This Part also authorizes any remaining balance in the Department of 23 
Administrative and Financial Services, Information Services program, General Fund 24 
account at the close of fiscal  year 2016 -17 to be carried forward into the new Department 25 
of Administrative and Financial Services, Central Administrative Applications program, 26 
General Fund account to be used for the same purposes.  27 
PART M  28 
 29 
This Part requires, as part of the transfers a t the close of the fiscal year, a transfer of 30 
$2,500,000 to the Maine Budget Stabilization Fund and $1,000,000 to the Capital 31 
Construction and Improvements Reserve Fund.  This Part also increases from $2,000,000 32 
to $2,500,000 the amount the State Controlle r may transfer from the unappropriated 33 
surplus of the General Fund for the purpose of amortizing the unfunded liability of retiree 34 
health benefits.  This Part also corrects a technical error.  35 
PART N  36 
 37 
This Part makes the following changes to the laws govern ing the Consensus 38 
Economic Forecasting Commission.  39 
1.  It allows the terms of commission members to be staggered.  40 
2.  It changes reporting requirements to conform to current practice and adds a 41 
requirement that at least 2 economic forecasts assuming potent ial economic recession 42 
scenarios be provided no later than February 1st in even -numbered years.  43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 820 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  3.  It changes the required number of meetings of the commission and the Revenue 1 
Forecasting Committee from 4 a year to 3.  2 
4.  It adds a requirement that the co mmission and the committee jointly issue a report 3 
to the Governor, the Legislative Council and the joint standing committee of the 4 
Legislature having jurisdiction over appropriations and financial affairs that uses the 5 
potential economic recession scenario s. 6 
PART O  7 
 8 
This Part transfers responsibility for the supervision and administrative control of risk 9 
management insurance, claims and loss control for the State from the Director of the 10 
Bureau of General Services and the Bureau of General Services to the S tate Controller 11 
and the Office of the State Controller.  12 
This Part also provides that the risk management division assists the State Controller 13 
in carrying out these duties and that the division is transferred from the Bureau of General 14 
Services to the Offi ce of the State Controller.  15 
PART P  16 
 17 
This Part authorizes the Department of Administrative and Financial Services, 18 
Bureau of General Services to accept contributions from public and private sources for 19 
the maintenance, repair and construction of state facil ities and provides that any earnings 20 
credited to the appropriate fund be used for the same purposes.  21 
PART Q  22 
 23 
This Part directs the Revisor of Statutes, when updating the Maine Revised Statutes, 24 
to change the name of the "displaced homemaker program" to the  "New Ventures Maine 25 
program" and the name of the "Displaced Homemakers Advisory Council" to the "New 26 
Ventures Maine Advisory Council."  This Part also changes the name of the Maine 27 
Centers for Women, Work and Community program to the New Ventures Maine pr ogram 28 
to reflect the name currently used by the University of Maine System.  29 
PART R  30 
 31 
This Part repeals the laws governing the Department of Administrative and Financial 32 
Services, Office of Information Technology and creates the Department of Technology 33 
Services. 34 
PART S  35 
 36 
This Part continues authorization for each individual tax expenditure provided by 37 
statute.  38

 40

develop the expertise of revenue agents and property appraisers.   Upon successful 42

PART V  4 
 5 
This Part repeals on July 1, 2018 the provision of law that places a cap on increases 6 
in the tax assessments to municipalities for correctional services.  This Part requires, 7 
beginning  July 1, 2018, the counties to fund the county jails and regional jail and to raise 8 
certain minimum amoun ts for correctional services, without any limits on increased 9 
assessments to the municipalities for correctional services.  10 
This Part requires the State Controller to transfer $12,202,104 from the 11 
unappropriated surplus of the General Fund to the Department  of Corrections, Reserve 12 
for County Jail Operations program, Other Special Revenue Funds and stipulates that the 13 
funds may not be transferred out of the Reserve for County Jail Operations program 14 
without legislative approval.  15

 17

Authority.  20

Economic and Community Development.  22 
3.  It moves administration of the ConnectME F und and the Municipal Gigabit 23 
Broadband Network Access Fund from the authority to the office, renames the 24 
ConnectME Fund the Broadband Development Fund and establishes that the funds are 25 
administered in consultation with the authority.  26

the attrition requirement for the District Attorneys Salaries program for the 2018 -2019 31 
biennium.  Thi s Part also requires the State Budget Officer to submit a report of the 32

Financial Affairs by September 1, 2018.  34

PART EEEE  19 
 20 
This Part repeals provisions of the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families, or 21 
TANF, and food supplement statutes that prohibit the Department of Health and Human 22 
Services from denying benefits based on a felony drug  conviction. It also establishes a 23 
requirement that to be eligible for TANF or food supplement benefits an individual must 24 
not have been convicted of a drug -related felony within 5 years of the date of application 25 
or while receiving benefits. This Part als o repeals the provision that allows the 26 
department to administer drug tests to convicted drug felons in the TANF program 27 
because it is no longer necessary due to the eligibility requirement.  28 
PART FFFF  29 
 30 
This Part makes the following changes to the laws gove rning the Temporary 31 
Assistance for Needy Families, or TANF, program.  32 
1.  It establishes asset and time limits for transitional child care services of $100,000 33 
and 18 months, respectively.  34 
2.  It shortens the lifetime limit on TANF benefits from 60 months t o 48 months.  35 
3.  It establishes the requirement for a TANF applicant to participate in a job 36 
readiness evaluation program prior to being granted TANF cash benefits.  37 
4.  It provides that for a first failure to meet the conditions of a family contract under 38 
TANF, termination of benefits is for 60 days and applies to the adult recipient and the full 39 
family unit and for a 2nd and subsequent violation, termination of benefits is for 90 days 40 
and applies to the adult recipient and the full family unit.  41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 830 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  5.  It amen ds the alternative aid laws to make such aid available no more than once 1 
every 24 months, instead of once every 12 months.  2 
6.  It removes all the good cause exceptions that prevent a person from being 3 
sanctioned under the ASPIRE -TANF program for failure to  participate in that program, 4 
with the exception of domestic violence.  5 
7.  It removes the 24 -month limit on education training and treatment for participants 6 
in the ASPIRE -TANF program in order to eliminate the difference between Maine and 7 
federal law rega rding the number of months of education and training that may qualify as 8 
countable work activities and specifies that accommodations for an individual with a 9 
disability are limited to those required by federal law. It amends laws governing the 10 
Parents as S cholars Program to specify that an enrollee in the program must meet federal 11 
work participation requirements.  12 
8.  It creates a penalty for quitting or losing a job for a recipient of TANF cash 13 
assistance if the job was quit or lost without good cause.  14 
9.  It establishes the Fund for the Payment of Federal Fines Imposed for 15 
Noncompliance with Federal Work Participation Requirements in the Department of 16 
Health and Human Services. The purpose of the fund is to pay fines imposed on the State 17 
by the Federal Gove rnment due to the State's failure to comply with federal requirements 18 
related to the ASPIRE -TANF program.  The Part requires the Commissioner of Health 19 
and Human Services to report annually regarding the fines owed by the State for 20 
noncompliance to the joi nt standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over 21 
health and human services matters, which is required to report out a bill, within 30 days 22 
of the commissioner's report, appropriating the amount necessary to pay the fines.  23 
PART GGGG  24 
 25 
This P art changes the disability determination cutoff from 45 days to 90 days for 26 
applications for aid based on a disability, and it eliminates the requirement to provide 27 
state-funded temporary medical coverage.  The Part also directs the Department of Health 28 
and Human Services to seek relief from any requirement in the Polk v. Longley  consent 29 
decree requiring the department to act on Medicaid applications within 45 days and 30 
provides that the change from 45 days to 90 days for applications for aid based on a 31 
disability does not take effect until the department receives that relief.  32 
PART IIII  33 
 34 
This Part specifies that the base year for the hospital tax is 2014.  35 
PART LLLL  36 
 37 
This Part contains transition provisions for the consolidation of accounts from the 38 
Department  of Health and Human Services, formerly the Department of Behavioral and 39 
Developmental Services, to the Department of Health and Human Services.  40

 5

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 832 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  PART TTTT  1 
 2 
This P art gives the Department of Health and Human Services the authority to adopt 3 
emergency rules to implement any provisions of this bill over which it has specific 4 
authority that has not been addressed by some other Part of the bill without the necessity 5 
of demonstrating that immediate adoption is necessary to avoid a threat to public health, 6 
safety or welfare.  7 
PART UUUU  8 
 9 
This Part amends the laws governing the Maine Commission on Indigent Legal 10 
Services.  It requires the eligibility standards developed by the  commission to take into 11 
account the ability of a person to make periodic installment payments toward counsel 12 
fees.  It requires the commission, at least every 5 years, to review the standards for 13 
evaluating counsel.  It modifies and adds to the duties of the commission.  It specifies that 14 
the executive director of the commission may contract for personnel.  It provides that 15 
non-General Fund funds received by the commission do not lapse at the end of the fiscal 16 
year.  It requires the executive director of t he commission to establish procedures to 17 
verify and review the eligibility of persons for indigent legal services and requires the 18 
executive director to provide the court information used to determine indigency for 19 
guidance to the court in determining a pe rson's financial ability to obtain private counsel.  20 
It provides for reimbursement and installment payments for persons determined by the 21 
court to be able to contribute to payment of assigned or contract counsel.  It exempts from 22 
the prohibition on disclos ing tax information the disclosure to the commission of tax 23 
information for the purpose of determining the eligibility for indigent legal services and 24 
the ability to reimburse expenses incurred by counsel.  25 
This Part requires the State Controller to transfe r $16,400,290 from the 26 
unappropriated surplus of the General Fund to the Maine Commission on Indigent Legal 27 
Services, Reserve for Indigent Legal Services program, Other Special Revenue Funds and 28 
stipulates that funds may not be transferred out of the Reser ve for Indigent Legal Services 29 
program without legislative approval.  30 
This Part also establishes the Working Group to Improve the Provision of Indigent 31 
Legal Services.  The working group consist of 11 members including 2 Senators and 2 32 
members of the House of Representatives.  The other members represent the other 33 
stakeholders, including 2 appointed by the Chief Justice of the Supreme Judicial Court. 34 
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the working group may access data 35 
maintained by the Maine Commiss ion on Indigent Legal Services and shall maintain the 36 
confidentiality of any confidential information provided to the working group.  The 37 
working group may invite the participation and input of additional interested parties and 38 
request information as neces sary to carry out its duties.  39 
The working group must submit a report, including recommendations, by December 40 
6, 2017.  The Joint Standing Committee on Judiciary may report out legislation to the 41 
Second Regular  Session of the 128th Legislature.  42 
PART VVVV  43 
 44 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 833 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  This Part delays the funding of the Fiscal Stability Program until the 2020 -2021 1 
biennial budget.  2 
PART WWWW  3 
 4 
This Part directs the State Controller to transfer funds from the Inland Fisheries and 5 
Wildlife Carrying Balances - General Fund account to the Enf orcement Operations - 6 
Inland Fisheries and Wildlife program, General Fund account to purchase one 7 
replacement aircraft engine in fiscal year 2017 -18 and one replacement aircraft engine in 8 
fiscal year 2018 -19. 9 
PART XXXX  10 
 11 
This Part increases compensation of active retired judges and justices of the state 12 
courts from $300 per day to $350 per day and from $175 per 1/2 day to $200 per 1/2 day.  13 
This Part also provides for a raise of 3% for judges and justices of the state courts for 14 
both fiscal year 2017 -18 and f iscal year 2018 -19. 15 
PART YYYY  16 
 17 
This Part clarifies that the record search fee schedule established by the State Court 18 
Administrator is for those record searches performed by Judicial Department employees 19 
and specifies that the record search fees deposited into the fund for use by the State Court 20 
Administrator to fund publications, forms and information technology are those fees for 21 
record searches performed by Judicial Department employees.  22 
This Part also allows the Supreme Judicial Court to raise or establ ish fees on online 23 
electronic case searches performed by Judicial Department employees, document delivery 24 
and case filings and surcharges on fines for the purpose of paying the cost of maintaining 25 
an electronic filing and court information management syste m. 26 
PART ZZZZ  27 
 28 
This Part provides that the members of the Maine Unemployment Insurance 29 
Commission must be sworn and may be removed by the Governor for inefficiency, 30 
willful neglect of duty or malfeasance in office, but only with the review and concurrence 31 
of the joint standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over labor matters 32 
upon hearing in executive session or by impeachment. Before removing a commission 33 
member, the Governor shall notify the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the 34 
House of Representatives of the removal and the reasons for the removal.  35 
PART AAAAA  36 
 37 
This Part moves the original jurisdiction of employer unemployment appeals cases 38 
from the Maine Unemployment Insurance Commission, the members of which are 39 
appointed by th e Governor, to the Department of Labor, Bureau of Unemployment 40 
Compensation, Division of Administrative Hearings to conform with federal law.  41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 834 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  This Part also revises the law to comply with Section 303(a)(3) of the federal Social 1 
Security Act, which requires  that the first level of appeals hearings must be conducted by 2 
a merit -staffed governmental employee in order to meet the impartial hearing requirement 3 
of Section 303(a)(3). For the purposes of this provision, "merit -staffed" means that the 4 
individuals are  subject to personnel standards based on a merit system and are not 5 
political appointees.  6 
PART BBBBB  7 
 8 
This Part repeals the provision of law that prohibits any unencumbered balance in the 9 
Competitive Skills Scholarship Fund from being used for a different purpose without 10 
legislative approval.  11 
PART CCCCC  12 
 13 
Section 1 of the Part changes the weekly benefit subtraction factor for partial 14 
unemployment from $25 to $100 to incentivize reemployment and connection to the 15 
workforce.  16 
The remainder of this Part changes the experience rating and the lowest tax schedule 17 
to make Maine unemployment tax rates more equitable. The chargeability of benefit 18 
charges is revenue neutral.  19 
PART DDDDD  20 
 21 
This Part authorizes the Department of Labor to identify positions to eliminate as t he 22 
result of ongoing reorganizations.  23 
PART EEEEE  24 
 25 
This Part establishes new surcharges on licenses issued by the Department of Marine 26 
Resources and directs the new surcharges to the Coastal Fisheries Research, Management 27 
and Enforcement Fund, Other Special  Revenue Funds account established in the 28 
department. The fund must be used to fund scientific research, management and 29 
enforcement activities related to marine resources.  30 
PART FFFFF  31 
 32 
This Part renames the Board of Registration for Professional Engineers p rogram 33 
within the Department of Professional and Financial Regulation the State Board of 34 
Licensure for Professional Engineers program.  35 
PART IIIII  36 
 37 
This Part provides that the Executive Director of the Gambling Control Unit has the 38 
authority to administer a nd enforce the provisions of the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 39 
17, chapter 13 -A governing the conduct of beano and Title 17, chapter 62 governing 40 
games of chance.  41 
PART JJJJJ  42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 835 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT   1 
This Part transfers the oversight, administration and enforcement of the Maine 2 
Revised Statutes, Title 17, chapter 13 -A governing beano from the Chief of the State 3 
Police to the Gambling Control Unit within the Department of Public Safety.  It reduces 4 
some requirements for organizations that conduct beano, such as requiring them to 5 
register with the Gambling Control Unit rather than apply for a license and to maintain 6 
records of the use of proceeds from beano rather than regularly file disposition of funds 7 
reports with the Gambling Control Unit.  High -stakes beano under Title 17, chapte r 13-A 8 
is still subject to licensure.  This Part also adds some provisions to Title 17, chapter 13 -A 9 
to permit schools, campgrounds and resorts to conduct beano for the entertainment of 10 
their guests, including children under 16 years of age, as long as cer tain requirements are 11 
met. 12 
PART KKKKK  13 
 14 
This Part transfers in the Department of Public Safety the oversight, administration 15 
and enforcement of the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 17, chapter 62 governing games of 16 
chance from a licensing unit to the Gambling Control Unit.  It reduces some requirements 17 
for organizations that conduct certain games of chance, such as requiring them to register 18 
with the Gambling Control Unit rather than apply for a license and maintaining records of 19 
the use of proceeds from games rather than regularly filing disposition of funds reports 20 
with the Gambling Control Unit.  Card games and most tournament games are still 21 
subject to licensure under this Part.  It adds a provision that permits the operation of 22 
cribbage tournaments for char itable purposes without a license.  These tournaments are 23 
not required to be conducted by a nonprofit organization and may be conducted in places 24 
like a restaurant or brewery tap room.  Entry fees are limited to $25, and all fees must be 25 
paid as prizes or donated to a verifiable charitable purpose.  It also makes changes 26 
regarding the conduct of raffles for charitable purposes, including a provision that permits 27 
the conduct of a raffle with a prize value up to $1,000 to be conducted by a person or 28 
organizat ion without having to be licensed by or registered with the Gambling Control 29 
Unit.  30 
PART LLLLL  31 
 32 
This Part provides that public safety inspectors in the Department of Public Safety, 33 
Office of the State Fire Marshal for the purpose of enforcing the Maine Revi sed Statutes, 34 
Title 25, section 2452, relating to statewide enforcement powers of the National Fire 35 
Protection Association No. 101, Life Safety Code, have the right to execute or serve 36 
criminal and civil violation process against offenders who violate the National Fire 37 
Protection Association No. 101, Life Safety Code.  38 
PART MMMMM  39 
 40 
This Part amends the law regarding examinations of plans for construction, 41 
reconstruction or repairs submitted to the Department of Public Safety by establishing a 42 
single fee sched ule for new construction, reconstruction, repairs and renovations of 1.5/10 43 
of 1% of the cost to construct or reconstruct the portion of the project subject to State Fire 44 
Marshal review.  45

PART SSSSS  24 
 25

This Part requires the Department of Correcti ons by February 15, 2018 to submit a 28

 36

Delivery of Local and Regional Services from the Department of Administrativ e and 38

Part also adds capital grants as a 3rd type of grant available from the fund; current law 40

PART VVVVV  42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 837 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT   1 
This Part provides for the creation of 9 to 12 school management and leadership 2 
centers. School administrative units may voluntarily establish a school management and 3 
leadership center through an interlocal agreement and may include associate members 4 
through c ontractual agreements or memoranda of understanding.  A school management 5 
and leadership center provides administrative and education functions in accordance with 6 
the interlocal agreement and functions as an extension of the schools that are members of 7 
the school management and leadership center.  Participating school administrative units 8 
voluntarily choose which educational functions or support services they purchase from a 9 
school management and leadership center.  10 
PART XXXXX  11 
 12 
This Part allows the Commissio ner of Education to authorize one additional public 13 
charter school in each school year through the 2021 -2022 school year once the statutory 14 
cap of 10 public charter schools is reached.  15 
PART YYYYY  16 
 17 
This Part establishes an annual open enrollment period for secondary students during 18 
which they may request to transfer to a public high school outside of their resident school 19 
administrative unit for the subsequent school year without the approval of their resident 20 
school administrative unit. This Part also requi res that parents of secondary students be 21 
notified of this option by March 1st of each year.  For the purposes of the Essential 22 
Programs and Services Funding Act, the residency of a student is considered to be the 23 
school administrative unit to which the st udent transferred.  24 
PART ZZZZZ  25 
 26 
This Part directs the Department of Education to establish education savings accounts 27 
for no more than 100 children with disabilities that may be used by the parents or legal 28 
guardians of such children for certain educational  purposes. The parent or legal guardian 29 
and the Department of Education must enter into a written agreement governing the terms 30 
of the account and how the funds will be used. The funding for these accounts would 31 
come from shifting 90% of the essential prog rams and services funding that would 32 
otherwise be provided by the State and the school administrative unit for the child into 33 
the savings account. The Part provides mechanisms for approval of educational 34 
expenditures and review of spending from the account s and provides a renewal process.  35 
PART AAAAAA  36 
 37 
This Part adds engaging in training and staff development for identification of and 38 
provision of intervention services for children with autism to the program functions of the 39 
Child Development Services System . 40 
PART BBBBBB  41 
 42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ C” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 838 - 128LR2175(04) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  This Part amends the career and technical education laws to enable career and 1 
technical education programs to serve students in grades 6 to 8.  2 
PART CCCCCC  3 
 4 
This Part requires the University of Maine System, the Maine Community College 5 
System  and the Maine Maritime Academy to report the cost to students of remedial 6 
courses in the subjects of English language arts and mathematics, by school 7 
administrative unit for students graduating within the prior 3 years from a school in that 8 
school adminis trative unit.  The Part requires the Commissioner of Education to reduce 9 
state subsidy to the school administrative units and to pay those funds to the higher 10 
education institution where the students took those remedial courses. Those higher 11 
education inst itutions are required to use the funds to reduce or eliminate the cost of 12 
remedial courses to their students and to report to the Commissioner of Education and the 13 
Legislature how those funds were used to achieve the reduction or elimination of those 14 
costs . 15 
PART DDDDDD  16 
 17 
This Part authorizes the State to bargain for a contract for standard salary and benefits 18 
for public education employees in participating school districts.  This Part also establishes 19 
annual targets for the percentage share of expenditures b y regional school units on direct 20 
instruction, which includes regular instruction, special education, career and technical 21 
education and other instruction including summer school and extracurricular instruction.  22 
PART EEEEEE  23 
 24 
This Part directs the Departmen t of Education to review the work of the 25 
public -private partnership Count ME In and to undertake a comprehensive attendance 26 
initiative to address truancy.  This Part also directs the department to report to the Joint 27 
Standing Committee on Education and Cul tural Affairs by January 31, 2018.  28

 30

make recommendations based upon this review to the Joint Standing Committee on 33 
Education and Cultural Affairs during the Second Regular Session of the 128th 34 
Legislature.  35

 37

Mental Health Services  program, General Fund account within the Department of Health 39 
and Human Services be carried forward for use by this program in the next fiscal year.  40

current fiscal year.  Finally, this Part authorizes the Department of Health and Human 25
